title: SCDSS v. Mangle
description: South Carolina Department of Social Services, Child Support Enforcement (DSS) appeals the family courts denial of its motion to continue child support until the childâ€™s graduation from high school.
text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
SCDSS Child Support Enforcement/Cindy Ruff, Plaintiffs
of whom SCDSS Child Support Enforcement is Appellant
v.
Ralph Mangle, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4130
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 3, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stacey L. Kaufman, S.C. Dept. of Social Services, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Ralph Mangle, Pro se, of Simpsonville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â South Carolina Department of Social Services, Child Support Enforcement (DSS) appeals the family courtâ€™s denial of its motion to continue child support until the childâ€™s graduation from high school.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Ralph Mangle is the father of Toran Mangle.Â  On October 31, 1991, custody of Toran was given to his mother, and Mr. Mangle was ordered to pay child support directly to the mother.Â  On January 17, 1996, Mr. Mangle was ordered to pay child support through the court.Â  Neither order addresses the termination of the child support obligation.Â  
In the fall of 2004, Toran began his senior year of high school and turned eighteen on September 14, 2004.Â  In March of 2005, Mr. Mangle informed the family court that Toran had turned eighteen.Â  On March 11, 2005, the family court terminated Mr. Mangleâ€™s child support obligation and dismissed the arreareage that had accrued after Toranâ€™s eighteenth birthday.Â  Neither DSS nor the mother was given an opportunity to be heard on the issue of termination before the courtâ€™s ruling.
DSS filed a motion for reconsideration on March 22, 2005, seeking modification of the March 11th order to provide child support until Toranâ€™s high school graduation in June 2005.Â  The motion for reconsideration was heard on April 21, 2005.Â  At the hearing, DSS presented evidence showing Toran was in his senior year of high school, was an A and B student, and had perfect attendance.Â  On June 1, 2005, the family court denied DSSâ€™s motion to continue the child support obligation because there was no existing order for child support beyond the eighteenth birthday.Â  DSS appeals this denial.
ANALYSIS
DSS argues the family court erred in not finding the child support order continued as a matter of law beyond Toranâ€™s eighteenth birthday until his graduation from high school or his nineteenth birthday.Â  We disagree. 
Child support awards are addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge and, absent an abuse of discretion, will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 92, 320 S.E.2d 706, 710 (1984). Â Prior to the 1996 amendment to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420, child support obligations generally ended by operation of law when the child reached majority. See Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 109, 492 S.E.2d 86, 93 (1997). 
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420 (A) (17) (Supp. 2005) gives family courts jurisdiction to make orders of child support and states, in pertinent part: 

(A) The family court has exclusive jurisdiction: (17) To make all orders for support run until further order of the court, except that orders for child support run until the child is eighteen years of age or until the child is married or becomes self‑supporting, as determined by the court, whichever occurs first or to provide for child support past the age of eighteen years if the child is in high school and is making satisfactory progress toward completion of high school, not to exceed the nineteenth birthday unless exceptional circumstances are found to exist or unless there is a preexisting agreement or order to provide for child support past the age of eighteen years. 

DSS argues this requires child support obligations to continue as a matter of law beyond the childâ€™s eighteenth birthday where the child is in high school and making satisfactory progress towards graduation even if the original support order is silent as to support past the eighteenth birthday. 
It is undisputed that the family court can order child support to continue beyond the age of eighteen for children who are in high school and are making satisfactory progress towards completion.Â  However, a lack of jurisdiction was not the basis of the family courtâ€™s denial.Â  The family courtâ€™s denial was based solely on procedure.Â  The authority to grant a specific form of relief does not mean that form of relief will automatically be granted.
Child support like all relief must be properly pleaded, noticed, and specifically granted by the court.Â  There was no existing order granting child support past the age of eighteen.Â  Neither the mother nor DSS had ever filed an action seeking the continuation of child support beyond Toranâ€™s eighteenth birthday.Â  See Dake v. Painter, 288 S.C. 118, 118, 341 S.E.2d 620, 620 (1986) (holding the family court had no authority to reduce amount or frequency of child support payments where neither was requested in the pleadings). Â The court dismissed the motion to reconsider without prejudice and informed DSS that the mother would need to seek a new order granting child support to cover the remaining period until the childâ€™s graduation or nineteenth birthday.Â  Accordingly, judgment of the family court is
AFFIRMED.[1]
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

[1]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Town of Hilton Head Island v. Godwin
description: The Town of Hilton Head Island appeals the order of the circuit court denying its motion to dismiss and granting a new trial in favor of Montgomery Godwin.  We vacate.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Town of Hilton Head Island, Appellant,
v.
Montgomery Godwin, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4131
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 3, 2006

VACATED


  
    
      
Marshall H. Waldron, Jr., of Bluffton, for Appellant.
Montgomery Godwin, pro se, of Bluffton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this action, the Town of Hilton Head Island (the Town) appeals the order of the circuit court denying its motion to dismiss and granting a new trial in favor of Montgomery Godwin.Â  We vacate.[1]
FACTS
In July 1995, Godwin received a citation charging him with criminal domestic violence.Â  The uniform traffic ticket set a trial date for August 8, 1995.Â  When Godwin failed to appear, the Hilton Head Island municipal court found him guilty, in absentia; assessed a $304 fine; and issued a bench warrant for his arrest.[2]Â  Godwin neither appealed the conviction nor took any other action to set aside the conviction.Â  On September 29, 1995, police arrested Godwin in connection with three outstanding arrest warrants, including the warrant issued following his CDV conviction.Â  That same day, Godwin, or someone on his behalf, paid the $304 fine in connection with the CDV conviction to obtain his release from custody.Â  Again, Godwin took no action related to the conviction. 
On August 11, 2003, Godwin applied for a gun permit pursuant to an employment opportunity.Â  A subsequent SLED investigation revealed the 1995 CDV conviction on his record.Â  Then, on March 26, 2004, approximately eight years after the CDV conviction, Godwin sent a letter to the Hilton Head Island Municipal Court, which the court treated as a motion to set aside the conviction and/or a motion for a new trial.Â  At the hearing before municipal court Judge James Herring, Godwin claimed the first notice he received of the CDV conviction was on August 11, 2003, and that the Town committed several procedural and clerical errors relating to his conviction for CDV that warranted his conviction be set aside or a new trial granted.Â  The Town argued the municipal court lacked the jurisdiction to entertain Godwinâ€™s motion because the motion was untimely.Â  The municipal court agreed and denied the motion, finding Godwinâ€™s actions were untimely.
Godwin appealed the municipal courtâ€™s order to the circuit court.Â  The Town filed a motion to dismiss, arguing the circuit court and the municipal court lacked jurisdiction to hear Godwinâ€™s motion.Â  At the motion hearing, Godwin again argued he did not receive notice of his 1995 CDV conviction until August 11, 2003, and that he discovered many procedural and clerical errors that warranted his conviction be set aside or a new trial granted.Â  The circuit court agreed with Godwin, denied the motion to dismiss, and granted a new trial based on â€œsubstantial justice.â€Â  The Townâ€™s motion to reconsider was denied, and this appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The appellate court must always take notice of the lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Amisub of S.C., Inc. v. Passmore, 316 S.C. 112, 114, 447 S.E.2d 207, 208 (1994).Â  The lack of subject matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, and can be raised sua sponte by the court. Â See, e.g., Lake v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 248, 498 S.E.2d 650, 653 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding issues related to subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time).Â  â€œThe acts of a court with respect to a matter as to which it has no jurisdiction are void.â€Â  State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 107, 572 S.E.2d 309, 311-12 (Ct. App. 2002). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Town argues the circuit court erred in denying its motion to dismiss and in granting Godwinâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  Specifically, the Town argues the circuit court lacked the jurisdiction necessary to entertain Godwinâ€™s motion.Â  We agree.
Rule 29(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure governs post trial motions from a conviction in magistrateâ€™s court and states, in part:

In cases involving appeals from convictions in magistrateâ€™s or municipal court, post trial motions shall be made within ten (10) days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment disposing of the appeal.

Furthermore, the supreme court has noted that â€œa partyâ€™s time to appeal from a judgment in a magistrateâ€™s court or move for a new trial therein ... begin[s] [when] he has notice of the judgment.â€Â  State v. Martin, 352 S.C. 32, 33, 572 S.E.2d 287, 288 (2002) (citing Brewer v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 261 S.C. 52, 56, 198 S.E.2d 256, 257 (1973)).Â  A party who fails to timely appeal or take any other timely action necessary to correct an error is procedurally barred from contesting the validity of the conviction.Â  Martin, 352 S.C. at 33, 572 S.E.2d at 288.
 Martin is analogous to the present case.Â  Because of a series of administrative errors, Martin was notified in December 1997, that she had been convicted, in absentia, of driving under the influence on August 26, 1997.Â  Martin, 352 S.C. at 33, 572 S.E.2d at 287.Â  A bench warrant was issued for Martinâ€™s arrest, and she paid the fine assessed by the municipal court.Â  Id.Â  Shortly thereafter, Martin notified the State, via her attorney, of the disposition of the ticket.Â  Id. at 33, 572 S.E.2d 288.Â  The State took no action at that time.Â  Nearly six months later, in June 1998, the State sought to reopen the case on the ground that the traffic ticket had been â€œsigned offâ€ in error.Â  Id. Â The circuit court ruled the Stateâ€™s efforts to set aside the conviction were untimely.Â  Id.Â  The supreme court agreed, finding the state took no action between December 1997 and June 1998 to rectify the situation or to notify Martin that her conviction had been erroneously entered.Â  The court, relying on Rule 29, SCRCrimP, held the Stateâ€™s â€œfailure to take any remedial action to remedy this situation in a timely manner therefore precluded its ability to challenge the entry of a conviction on the DUI first ticket.â€Â  Id. at 34, 572 S.E.2d at 288.
In this matter, Godwin had notice of his 1995 CDV conviction no later than September 29, 1995, when he was arrested under the bench warrant and his release was secured by payment of the fine imposed by the municipal court after the 1995 conviction.Â  Under Rule 29, SCRCrimP, Godwin had until October 9, 1995 to file any post trial motions or his notice of appeal.Â  Godwin failed to take any remedial actions at that time.Â  His motion to set aside the 1995 conviction came in March 2004, approximately eight years after he received notice of the conviction.Â  Similar to the Stateâ€™s inaction in Martin, Godwinâ€™s inaction precludes his ability to challenge the 1995 conviction.Â  Therefore, the municipal court correctly held Godwinâ€™s challenge to his conviction was untimely, and the circuit court erred in failing to grant the Townâ€™s motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction.Â Â Â Â Â  
Assuming, arguendo, notice was not received until August 11, 2003, the date Godwin admitted he received notice of the 1995 conviction, his motion would still be untimely.Â  Godwin took no action from August 11, 2003 until his letter to the municipal court on March 26, 2004, some seven months from the date he claimed he received notice of the conviction.Â  Accordingly, as Godwin concedes he had actual notice of the 1995 conviction on August 11, 2003, and he failed to timely appeal or take any other action to correct the matter, he is now procedurally barred from contesting the validity of the 1995 conviction. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is hereby
 VACATED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Godwin agreed that the municipal court found him guilty, in absentia, but he denied receiving notice until August 11, 2003.Â

title: Doe v. Doe
description: In this action for divorce and equitable distribution, Wife appeals the family court's identification, valuation, and distribution of the marital estate.  In addition, Wife appeals the family court's award of attorneys' fees, costs, and certain advancements to Husband.  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
text:
Doe v. Doe


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John Doe, Respondent,
v.
Jane Doe, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
 Rolly W. Jacobs, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4132
Heard May 9, 2006 â€“ Filed Â July 3, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Emma I. Bryson, of Columbia and William S. Tetterton, of Camden, for Appellant.
George W. Speedy, of Camden, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this action for divorce and equitable distribution, Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s identification, valuation, and distribution of the marital estate.Â  In addition, Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s award of attorneysâ€™ fees, costs, and certain advancements to Husband.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
Wife and Husband were married on September 8, 1970, when Husband was seventeen and Wife was sixteen.Â  Husband worked as a construction laborer until he began his own construction company in the 1980s.Â  For the first fourteen years of their marriage, Wife had numerous jobs, one of which was at Jubilee Embroidery.Â  At some time in the mid to late 1970s, while employed at Jubilee, Wife began having an affair with her boss (Paramour).Â  In 1984, Wife ceased working after giving birth to a daughter (Daughter). 
Although the parties had very few assets when their marriage began, they amassed a fairly large estate over the years.Â  Husbandâ€™s construction business was profitable, and Wife worked for the business approximately one day a week, keeping the books and offering decorating services.Â  In 2002, after Daughter graduated from high school and moved out of the home to attend college, Wife asked Husband for a divorce.Â  Husband testified he became suspicious when Wife refused to attempt marriage counseling.Â  He hired a private investigator, who observed Wife entering a motel with Paramour.Â  Husband recognized Paramour, not only because he had been Wifeâ€™s former boss, but also because Paramour was a longtime family friend.Â  Wife later admitted the affair had been going on for more than twenty years.Â  
Upon learning of the adultery, Husband called Paramourâ€™s wife to inform her of the relationship between their spouses.Â  After speaking with her, Husband suspected the daughter he had raised might not be his biological child.Â  He later had a DNA test, which confirmed his suspicions that Paramour was Daughterâ€™s biological father.[1]Â  
Subsequently, Husband filed a complaint in the family court, asking for, among other things, a divorce on the grounds of adultery and an equitable distribution of the marital property.Â  Notably, Husband did not seek a ruling regarding Daughterâ€™s paternity.Â  In Wifeâ€™s answer, she admitted the adultery.Â  
At the final hearing, the parties presented evidence of the valuation of the marital property, the quality of Husband and Wifeâ€™s relationship before separation, the costs associated with the divorce, and various advances made by Husband between the time of filing for divorce and the time of the hearing.Â  Additionally, Husband presented evidence indicating Daughter was not his biological child and introduced the testimony of Dr. Perry Woodside, an economist, to establish the cost of raising a child.Â  The family court issued a divorce decree granting Husband a divorce on the grounds of adultery; barring alimony to Wife; valuing the marital property at $1,332,798; awarding Husband seventy percent of the marital property; and ordering Wife to reimburse Husband for his advances, his attorneysâ€™ fees, his accountantâ€™s fees, and the cost of Dr. Woodsideâ€™s testimony.Â  Wife submitted a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend this decree, which the family court denied.Â Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, the appellate court has
the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  However, â€œbecause the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.â€Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Identification and Valuation of Marital Property
Wife contends the family court erred in identifying and valuing the marital property.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.
To preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 73, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œError preservation requirements are intended â€˜to enable the lower court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and arguments.â€™â€Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (quoting Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000)).Â  Without an initial ruling by the trial court, a reviewing court simply is not able to evaluate whether the trial court committed error.Â  Id.Â  Therefore, when an appellant neither raises an issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, Â motion, the issue is not preserved for appellate review. Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992).
At trial, Wife made no arguments with respect to the valuation of the marital property.Â  Additionally, Wife failed to specifically raise any issues with regard to valuation in her Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Instead, she generally asserted that the divorce decree was unsupported by the evidence and that the family court judge failed to properly apply the equitable division statute.Â  These broad assertions failed to preserve her appellate arguments relating to the identification and valuation of the marital estate.
II. Daughterâ€™s Paternity
Wife argues the family court erred in making findings of facts that essentially determined Daughterâ€™s paternity.Â  This issue has also not been preserved for our review.Â  
Wife objected at trial to the consideration of Daughterâ€™s paternity, and the family court assured her that a â€œdetermination as to whether or not the child is bastardized . . . is not a finding for the Court to make.â€Â  The family court later stated â€œ[t]here will be no finding as to the paternity of the child.â€Â  However, in its written order, the family court found that â€œalthough the question of paternity was not before the Court, DNA testing and the admission of the wife has proven that the child is not the biological daughter of [Husband].â€Â  Although Wife made a motion to alter or amend the family courtâ€™s order, she did not ask the family court to reconsider this finding. Under these circumstances, Wife failed to preserve this issue for our review.Â  See Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. of Horry-Georgetown, Inc. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 60, 427 S.E.2d 673, 675 (1993) (holding when trial courtâ€™s oral and written orders are inconsistent, appellant must bring these inconsistencies to the trial courtâ€™s attention through a motion to alter or amend to preserve the issue for appeal).[2]Â  
III. Equitable Distribution
Wife argues the family court erred in distributing seventy percent of the marital property to Husband.Â  Specifically, Wife contends the family court erred in considering the paternity of Daughter as a factor in equitable distribution, intimating that the length of the marriage favored Husband, penalizing Wife for her marital misconduct, and undervaluing her contribution to the marital estate.Â  We agree.
The division of marital property is in the family courtâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of that discretion. Â Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 290, 617 S.E.2d 359, 361 (2005).Â  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides fifteen factors for the family court to consider in apportioning marital property and affords the family court with the discretion to give weight to each of these factors â€œas it finds appropriate.â€Â  On appeal, this court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment, and it is irrelevant that this court might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court.Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Even if the family court commits error in distributing marital property, that error will be deemed harmless if the overall distribution is fair.Â  See West v. West, 315 S.C. 44, 46, 431 S.E.2d 603, 604 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
In awarding Husband seventy percent of the marital estate, the family court found â€œthe two controlling factorsâ€ were the duration of the marriage and the conduct of the parties. Â The family court went on to say the marriageâ€™s dissolution was â€œsolely at the hands of [Wife]â€ and Wife â€œduped her spouse through at least twenty years of the thirty-two year marriage into believing that he should love her.â€Â  Additionally, the family court noted that Husbandâ€™s contribution to the marital estate was ninety to ninety-five percent and that Dr. Woodsideâ€™s testimony, which outlined the cost of raising a child, was relevant to the courtâ€™s equitable apportionment determination. 
We find the family courtâ€™s seventy-thirty split in favor of Husband constituted an abuse of discretion.Â  This was a marriage of significant duration.Â  While there is certainly no recognized presumption in favor of a fifty-fifty division, we approve equal division as an appropriate starting point for a family court judge attempting to divide an estate of a long-term marriage. Â See Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina 321-22 (3rd ed. 2001 and Supp. 2005) (â€œAlthough neither the case decisions nor the Equitable Apportionment of Marital Property Act say so directly, the results in cases involving long marriages would lead one to predict that, absent special circumstances, marital property will be divided on a 50-50 basis . . . .â€). Â Case law seems to bear out this trend.Â  See id. (citing Craig v. Craig, 358 S.C. 548, 595 S.E.2d 837 (Ct. App. 2004) (upholding a 50-50 division of marital property following a twenty-seven-year marriage), affâ€™d by 365 S.C. 285, 617 S.E.2d 359 (2005); Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 557 S.E.2d 693 (Ct. App. 2001) (affirming a 50-50 split in a sixteen year marriage that ended because of husbandâ€™s adultery); Mallet v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 473 S.E.2d 804 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting the family courtâ€™s 50-50 split was â€œgenerous,â€ but ultimately affirming the award, which followed a twenty-one year marriage); Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 478 S.E.2d 854 (Ct. App. 1994) (affirming the family courtâ€™s 50-50 split where the parties had been married over thirty years);Â  Murray v. Murray, 312 S.C. 154, 439 S.E.2d 312 (Ct. App. 1993) (affirming the family courtâ€™s award to Wife of a fifty percent â€œspecial equity interestâ€ in the appreciated value of the family home, which was Husbandâ€™s nonmarital property, following a seventeen-year marriage); Harlan v. Harlan, 300 S.C. 537, 389 S.E.2d 165 (Ct. App. 1990) (affirming a 50-50 division of marital property following an eighteen-year marriage); Kirsch v. Kirsch, 299 S.C. 201, 203, 383 S.E.2d 254, 255 (Ct. App. 1989) (affirming a 50-50 split and stating: â€œThis was a marriage of thirty years.Â  While Mr. Kirsch provided the bulk of the income, Mrs. Kirsch was a homemaker and she also worked for approximately twelve years outside the home.â€); Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 363 S.E.2d 404 (Ct. App. 1987) (affirming a 50-50 split in a marriage that lasted eighteen years, during which time Wife provided homemaker services and occasionally worked outside the home); Leatherwood v. Leatherwood, 293 S.C. 148, 359 S.E2d 89 (Ct. App. 1987) (affirming a 50-50 split of marital property following a twenty-two year marriage)).Â Â  
We recognize that in many long-term marriages, one spouse becomes the primary breadwinner while the other spouse makes less or even no money in order to have the flexibility to keep the household running smoothly. Â This arrangement is agreed upon, often implicitly, among the parties, and it would be unfair to the spouse who undertook household duties for the family court to apportion the marital estate solely based on the partiesâ€™ direct financial contributions.Â  See Walker v. Walker, 295 S.C. 286, 289, 368 S.E.2d 89, 90 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œEquitable distribution is based on a recognition that marriage is, among other things, an economic partnership.â€).
This equal division of marital assets can, of course, be altered in favor of one spouse depending on the circumstances of each case.Â  Here, for instance, Wifeâ€™s adultery caused the breakup of the marriage, an appropriate consideration for equitable apportionment.Â  However, we have consistently held that fault does not justify a severe penalty. [3]Â Â  See Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 236, 512 S.E.2d 539, 546 (Ct. App. 1999); Rampey v. Rampey, 286 S.C. 153, 156, 332 S.E.2d 213, 214 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  We believe that Wifeâ€™s adultery, alone, does not justify a forty percent differential between her portion of the marital estate and Husbandâ€™s portion.Â  Indeed, such a lopsided division could only be sustainable if our equitable division laws sanction the consideration of fault as a permissible punitive factor.Â  Our law is to the contrary, expressly disallowing fault as a penalty.Â  Thus, Wifeâ€™s adultery does not justify a forty percent equitable division differential.
In arriving at its seventy-thirty division, the family court specifically found Dr. Woodsideâ€™s testimony regarding the cost of raising a child relevant.Â  However, the issue of paternity was never properly before the court.Â  In fact, Husbandâ€™s complaint alleged that â€œof this marriage one child has been born, namely, [Daughter].â€Â  Because paternity was not an issue, the cost of raising Daughter, who was born during the marriage, was not relevant, and the family court erred in considering the testimony.
In light of the marriageâ€™s longevity, our prohibition against imposing a severe penalty for fault, and the family courtâ€™s erroneous consideration of Dr. Woodsideâ€™s testimony, we find the family court abused its discretion when it awarded Husband seventy percent of the marital estate.Â  We believe the more equitable division would be sixty percent to Husband and forty percent to Wife. [4]
IV. Advancements
Wife argues the family court erred in ordering her to reimburse Husband for certain advancements made on behalf of Wife.[5] Wife specifically contends Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 486 S.E.2d 516 (Ct. App. 1997), provides that these payments, to the extent they are voluntary, do not entitle Husband to reimbursement.Â  However, Wife did not raise this issue to the family court and did not challenge this portion of the ruling in her Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.[6]Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (holding when an appellant neither raises an issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to amend, the issue is not presented properly to an appellate court for review); Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 73, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review).
V. Attorneysâ€™ Fees and Cost of Dr. Woodsideâ€™s Testimony
Wife argues the family court erred in ordering her to pay all of Husbandâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees.[7]Â  Additionally, Wife contends the family court erred in admitting the testimony of Dr. Woodside and ordering her to pay the costs associated with his testimony.Â  We address these issues separately below. 
A. Attorneysâ€™ Fees
Wife argues the family court erred in ordering her to pay all of Husbandâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees. We agree.Â  
Attorneysâ€™ fees may be assessed against a party in an action brought in the family court.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2005); Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  The award of attorneysâ€™ fees is within the discretion of the court.Â  Hailey v. Hailey, 357 S.C. 18, 31, 590 S.E.2d 495, 502 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision regarding attorneysâ€™ fees will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Green v. Green, 320 S.C. 347, 353, 465 S.E.2d 130, 134 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
â€œAn order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of law to support the courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  Rule 26(a), SCRFC.Â  â€œOur case law and court rules make clear that when a contract or statute authorizes an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the trial court must make specific findings of fact on the record for each of the required factors to be considered.â€Â  Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 646, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534-35 (Ct. App. 1998). Â â€œ[W]hen an Order is issued in violation of Rule 26(a), this Court may remand the matter to the trial court or, where the record is sufficient, make its own findings of fact in accordance with the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Holcombe v. Hardee, 304 S.C. 522, 524, 405 S.E.2d 821, 822 (1991); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 203, 522 S.E.2d 835, 839 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
In deciding whether to award attorneysâ€™ fees, the family court should consider: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial condition of each party; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 28, 624 S.E.2d 643, 648-49 (2006); Browning v. Browning, 366 S.C. 255, 269, 621 S.E.2d 389, 396 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  To determine the amount of an award of attorneysâ€™ fees, the court should consider: the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case; counselsâ€™ professional standing; the contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991); Deidun v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 65, 606 S.E.2d 489, 499 (Ct. App. 2004).
Here, in the family courtâ€™s prelude to awarding attorneysâ€™ fees to Husband, the court noted: â€œ[Husband] has incurred certain expenses in the bringing and maintaining of this action which would have not been necessary but for the conduct of [Wife].â€ Â After listing the amount of Husbandâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees, the family court specifically found â€œthe reason [Wife] should bear these costs is that her adultery caused the divorce in spite of [Husbandâ€™s] willingness to reconcile and her unwillingness to do so and because of the deception throughout the marriage concerning her adulterous activities and the birth of the child by [Wifeâ€™s] paramour.â€ Â A partyâ€™s fault in causing a divorce, however, is not a factor to be considered when awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Furthermore, although the family court went on to consider factors that are relevant, such as the effect ordering attorneyâ€™s fees would have on Wifeâ€™s standard of living, Wifeâ€™s ability to pay the fees, and the beneficial results obtained by Husbandâ€™s attorneys, the family court neglected to consider two factors that weigh in Wifeâ€™s favor: Husbandâ€™s ability to pay and the relative financial situations of the parties.Â  See Upchurch, 367 S.C. at 28, 624 S.E.2d at 648-49; Browning, 366 S.C. at 269, 621 S.E.2d at 396.Â  Husband has earned a comfortable living with his construction business, and his employment status will not change as a result of the divorce.Â  Conversely, Wife has only her share of the equitable distribution with which to pay these costs and must enter the workforce after a nearly twenty-year absence. Â We further note that our opinion today has reduced the beneficial results obtained by Husband.
Under these circumstances, we hold the family court erred in ordering Wife to pay Husbandâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Considering the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees, the beneficial results obtained by Husbandâ€™s attorneys, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living, we believe Husband and Wife should be responsible for their own attorneysâ€™ fees. 
B. Cost of Husbandâ€™s Economic Expert
Wife contends the family court erred in ordering her to pay the costs of Dr. Woodside because his testimony was not relevant to equitable distribution. We agree the testimony of Dr. Woodside was irrelevant to this case and therefore hold the family court abused its discretion in ordering Wife to pay his costs.Â  
An award of litigation expenses rests within the sound discretion of the trial court and should not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Ellerbe v. Ellerbe, 323 S.C. 283, 298, 473 S.E.2d 881, 889 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The same considerations that apply to awarding attorneysâ€™ fees also apply to awarding litigation expenses.Â  Id.; see also Nienow v. Nienow, 268 S.C. 161, 173, 232 S.E.2d 504, 510 (1977) (holding the same equitable considerations apply in awarding attorneysâ€™ fees and costs of litigation).Â  
â€œâ€˜Relevant evidenceâ€™ means evidence having any tendency to make, the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  â€œEvidence which is not relevant is not admissible.â€Â  Rule 402,
SCRE.  
As discussed earlier, Daughterâ€™s paternity was not an issue in this case.Â  Indeed, Husbandâ€™s own pleadings acknowledged she was his daughter.Â  Therefore, the amount of money Husband spent on support for her was not relevant.Â  Accordingly, the family court erred in admitting the testimony of Dr. Woodside and ordering Wife to pay his costs.
CONCLUSION

We find Wife failed to preserve the issues of the family courtâ€™s identification and valuation of the marital property, determination of Daughterâ€™s paternity, and award of advancements to Husband.Â  We find the family court erred in awarding Husband seventy percent of the marital estate, and modify the division to a sixty-forty split in favor of Husband.Â  Additionally, we find the family court erred in ordering Wife to pay Husbandâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees and the fees for Dr. Woodside.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Although the results of this test were not entered into evidence, Husband testified to the results without objection from Wifeâ€™s counsel.Â  Furthermore, Wife testified she â€œhad been told that [Paramour] was declared the father.â€Â  
[2] To the extent the proceedings here can be interpreted as an adjudication of paternity, we note this decision has no effect on Daughter.Â  See 
    Palm v. General Painting Co., Inc., 302 S.C. 372, 374, 396 S.E.2d 361, 362 (1990) (holding child is not bound by prior adjudication of paternity in divorce proceeding).
[3] In defending the family courtâ€™s division, Husband points out that in Simmons v. Simmons, 275 S.C. 41, 267 S.E.2d 427 (1980), our supreme courtÂ  upheld an apportionment of twenty-three percent of marital property to wife after her affair despite her contributions to the thirty-year marriage.Â  We note, however, that this case was decided in 1980, six years prior to the enactment of section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code.
[4] To accomplish this new division, Husbandâ€™s share of the Bank of Camden account will be reduced to $326,180, and Wifeâ€™s share of the account will be increased to $242,511.Â  With these new figures, Husband will receive $799,730 of the overall estate, and Wife will receive $533,068 of the marital estate.
[5] Some of these advancements were made to Daughter.Â  The family court required Wife to reimburse Husband for half of these advancements. Â Â 
[6] Not only was this issue not raised to the family court in a Rule 59(e) motion, but Wife also did not object to Husband entering in evidence a document outlining these expenses.
[7] Wife also asserts the family court erred in requiring her to pay Husbandâ€™s accountantâ€™s fee.Â  However, in support of this argument she merely states â€œthe accountantâ€™s fee was incorrect,â€ and she does not explain why it was incorrect.Â  Because Wife fails to point out a specific error, we deem her argument abandoned on appeal.Â  State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 16-17, 518 S.E.2d 278, 283 (Ct. App. 1999) (explaining that conclusory arguments are deemed abandoned on appeal).

text:
Siau v. Kassel


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Patrick M. Siau and Nancy S. Siau, as Co-Trustees of the Siau Qualified Personal Residence Trust Dated January 25, 2002, Raymond A. Pendleton and Jean C. Pendleton,
Respondents,
v.
Kal Kassel, Millard Dozier and Robert M.
Rogerson, Defendants and Third Party Plaintiffs,
of whom Kal Kassel is Appellant,
v.
Hagley Estates Property Owners Association, The County of Georgetown and the State of South Carolina, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Benjamin H. Culbertson, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No.Â  4133
Heard May 11, 2006 â€“ Filed July 3, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert J. Moran, of Murrells Inlet, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster and Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, Jr., all of Columbia; Charles T. Smith, of Georgetown; Ed Kelaher and Sid Connor, both of Surfside Beach; Jack M. Scoville and Joe Michael Crosby, both of Georgetown; Linda Weeks Gangi, of Conway, for Respondents.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  Kal Kassel appeals from a decision restraining and enjoining him from building any permanent structure within thirty feet of his rear property line and ordering him to remove all permanent structures currently located within thirty feet of his rear property line.Â  Kassel contends the trial court erred in determining ownership of land through the â€œPublic Trust Doctrine,â€ balancing the equities, and failing to determine his rights against Georgetown County.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1997, Kassel and Millard Dozier purchased a single lot bordering the Waccamaw River in a Georgetown County residential subdivision known as Hagley Estates. Â Kassel, a licensed real estate agent, and Dozier, a licensed builder, then legally split the single lot into two separate lots by filing a new plat with Georgetown County in 1997.Â  Kassel and Dozier split the lot into two â€œflag lotsâ€ with the intention to build a house on each lot. [1] Â  
Kassel and Dozier built a house on one of their two newly created lots (Lot 11) and sold this property to Ray Pendleton.Â  Kassel later bought Dozierâ€™s interest in the remaining lot (Lot 12), and he became the sole owner of the property.Â  After spending several years considering whether to sell Lot 12, Kassel informed Pendleton that he was going to build his own home on the lot â€œright up to the bulkhead.â€ [2] Â  
Pendleton, concerned that Kasselâ€™s house would partially obstruct his view of the river, declared that Kassel could not build there and asserted he would sue him if he tried.Â  Kassel responded that he had already received approval.Â  
Kasselâ€™s architect, Dwayne Vernon, presented his building plan to both the Georgetown County Zoning Office and the Hagley Estates Property Ownerâ€™s Association (the Association), and this plan was approved by both.Â  Vernon also contacted the Office of Coastal Resource Management (OCRM) and the Army Corps of Engineers, and both groups stated they had no issue with him building up to the bulkhead.Â  
Georgetown County maintains a fifteen-foot rear setback requirement for Kasselâ€™s property, and the Association maintains a thirty-foot rear setback requirement. Â Kassel and his architect represented to the county zoning department that Kassel owned not only Lot 12, but also the adjacent cypress flats which lie between the bulkhead on Lot 12 and the Waccamaw River.Â  The cypress flats are strips of tidal land that lie between the mean high water mark (MHWM) and the mean low water mark of the tidal Waccamaw River. Kassel intended to use the cypress flats to comply with the rear setback requirements.Â  
When Kassel began building his home as planned, Pendleton contacted the county zoning department to inquire about Kasselâ€™s permit.Â  Pendleton was told the permit was granted, but his concerns about Kassel building so close to the bulkhead would be investigated.Â  Having received no further response from the county, Pendleton spoke with other neighboring landowners. Â These neighbors, the Siaus, would have their view of the river completely obstructed by Kasselâ€™s house.Â  Therefore, the Siaus also contacted county zoning to prevent construction of the house.Â  Â Â Â Â Â  
After repeatedly attempting to contact OCRM, the Army Corps of Engineers, and several county officials over a period of several months, Pendleton and the Siaus were finally able to meet with the county to review Kasselâ€™s building plans.Â  Pendleton and the Siaus contended Kassel did not own the cypress flats, and therefore, he was not in compliance with the rear setback requirements. Â The county agreed, and on August 25, 2003, approximately 120 days after construction began, the county posted a stop work order for the construction of Kasselâ€™s house.Â  
Kassel appealed the stop work order to the Georgetown County Construction Board of Adjustments and Appeals (the Board).Â  On September 16, 2003, a hearing was held before the Board.Â  The Board, after hearing testimony and reviewing pertinent documentation, found in favor of Kassel and rescinded the stop work order.Â  
On September 17, 2003, the Pendletons and the Siaus (collectively, Plaintiffs) filed a verified complaint against Kassel and Dozier alleging the construction on Lot 12 violated rear setback requirements.[3]Â  Accompanying this complaint was Plaintiffsâ€™ motion to temporarily restrain and preliminarily enjoin Kassel from continuing his construction during the pendency of the case.Â  Kassel and Dozier answered Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint and filed third party complaints against Georgetown County, the Association, and the State of South Carolina.[4]Â  In addition to their complaint, Plaintiffs appealed the Boardâ€™s decision to rescind the stop work order, and the trial court incorporated this separate appeal into the instant action.Â  
The trial court found in favor of Plaintiffs, restrained and enjoined Kassel from building any permanent structure within thirty feet of his rear property line, ordered him to remove all permanent structures located within thirty feet of his rear property line, and dismissed as moot Plaintiffsâ€™ appeal of the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  Kassel now appeals.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is
in equity.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001).Â  On appeal of an equitable action tried by a master, the court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence. Id.Â  However, the appellate court is not required â€œto ignore the findings below when the trial court was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Marshland Trust, Inc., 358 S.C. 655, 661, 596 S.E.2d 380, 383 (Ct. App. 2004).Â Â  
A decision whether to grant or deny an injunction is ordinarily left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is either unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Ledford v. Pennsylvania Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 671, 675, 230 S.E.2d 900, 383 (1976) (citations omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Public Trust Doctrine
Kassel contends his use of tidal wetlands as his rear setback does not violate the public trust doctrine.Â  Kassel argues neither his neighbors nor Georgetown County should be allowed to utilize the doctrine as a weapon to prevent his use of the cypress flats.Â  We disagree.
Under the public trust doctrine, the State holds presumptive title to land below the high water mark.Â  McQueen v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 354 S.C. 142, 149, 580 S.E.2d 116, 119 (2003).Â  â€œ[N]ot only does the State hold title to this land in jus privatum, it holds it in jus publicum, in trust for the benefit of all the citizens of this State.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe Stateâ€™s presumptive title may be overcome only by showing a
specific grant from the sovereign [either the King of England or the State] which is strictly construed against the grantee.â€Â  Id. at 149 n.6, 580 S.E.2d at 119 n.6.Â  The Stateâ€™s presumptive title applies to tidelands.Â  Id. at 149-50, 580 S.E.2d at 120. 
Kassel did not erect any structure or commit any encroachment upon land below the MHWM.Â  Therefore, we agree with his assertion that building his home up to the bulkhead does not violate the public trust doctrine.Â  However, his compliance with the doctrine is irrelevant to the disposition of this matter.Â  The only relevancy of the doctrine in this dispute is with regard to determining ownership of the cypress flats.Â  
Because Kassel admits he cannot overcome the Stateâ€™s presumption of ownership of the cypress flats, it is undisputed that he does not own this land.Â  Kassel seeks to use land he does not own to satisfy both the county and the Associationâ€™s rear setback requirements.Â  It is as a result of these setback violations, not a violation of the public trust doctrine, that Kassel has been enjoined from building his house up to the bulkhead.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
Because Kassel does not own the cypress flats, his lot essentially ends at the bulkhead.Â  Thus, his house would have to be no less than thirty feet away from the bulkhead.Â  Kasselâ€™s house clearly violates the setback requirements in that it is less than thirty feet from the bulkhead.[5]Â  We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s interpretation and use of the public trust doctrine.
II.Â  Balancing of the Equities
Kassel contends the trial court erred in balancing the equities.Â  He argues he should not be required to remove, redesign, and reconstruct his home when he had no knowledge or fault in creating the problem, and Plaintiffsâ€™ only damages are a diminished view of the river.Â  We disagree.
As voluntary contracts, restrictive covenants will be enforced unless they are indefinite or contravene public policy.Â  Houck v. Rivers, 316 S.C. 414, 416, 450 S.E.2d 106, 108 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The Associationâ€™s applicable restrictive covenant states: Â â€œNo residence constructed on this lot, including porches or projections, shall be erected less than thirty (30) feet from the front lot line nor thirty (30) feet from the rear lot line.â€Â  The Associationâ€™s restrictive covenants further provide that â€œany person or persons owning real property in Hagley Estates Subdivisionâ€ may seek enforcement of the restrictive covenants.Â  We do not find these restrictive covenants to be indefinite or in contravention of public policy.
Kassel asks us to balance the equities in the application of the restrictive covenants.Â  â€œAlthough an injunction, like all equitable remedies, is granted as a matter of sound judicial discretion, and not as a matter of legal right, the right of a plaintiff to an injunction to enforce restrictive covenants has long received special treatment.â€Â  Id. at 418, 450 S.E.2d at 109 (citation omitted).Â  Generally, a restrictive covenant will be enforced regardless of the amount of damage
that will result from the breach and even though there is no substantial monetary damage to the complainant by reason of the violation.Â  Id. at 419, 450 S.E.2d at 109.Â  â€œThe mere breach alone is grounds for injunctive relief.â€Â  Id.  
Based on Houck, we do not need to reach the issue of â€œbalancing the equitiesâ€ in order to enforce restrictive covenants.Â  However, we will undertake a brief analysis.Â  In evaluating a request for injunction, the equities of both sides are to be considered, and each case must be decided on its own particular facts through a â€œbalancing of the equities.â€Â  MailSource, LLC v. M.A. Bailey & Assocs., 356 S.C. 363, 368, 588 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 2003).
Kasselâ€™s first indication that his ownership of the cypress flats was tenuous at best should have been when he was provided a quit-claim deed to this property in exchange for five dollars.Â  A second indication of a potential ownership problem was the fact Kassel was never able to attain title insurance for the cypress flats.Â  Kassel, a licensed real estate agent himself, should have realized that his ownership of the cypress flats was far from certain.Â  
Kassel argues that he received permission from all of the necessary organizations to proceed with his desired building plan, but the building plans submitted to the county zoning office and the Association represented that Kassel owned the cypress flats.Â  In fact, Kasselâ€™s architect admitted that he told the zoning officer that Kassel owned the cypress flats.Â  It was based on this misrepresentation that the zoning officer gave her approval to the building plan.Â  Additionally, prior to the commencement of any construction on Lot 12, Pendleton informed Kassel of his intent to sue if Kassel built up to the bulkhead.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
While removal of the partially constructed home will result in a hardship to Kassel, we find that Kassel was not without fault or knowledge of a potential problem with his desired building plan.Â  After balancing the equities, we find the granting of the permanent injunction was appropriate under the facts of this case.Â  Â Â 
III.Â  Laches
Kassel contends Plaintiffs should have been prevented from seeking an
injunction under the equitable doctrine of laches. He argues that Plaintiffsâ€™ delay in asserting their rights was unreasonable.Â  We disagree. 
â€œLaches is the negligent failure to act for an unreasonable period of time.â€Â  Gibbs v. Kimbrell, 311 S.C. 261, 269, 428 S.E.2d 725, 730 (Ct. App. 1993) (emphasis in original).Â  Courts of equity will refuse to protect a partyâ€™s rights if the partyâ€™s delay in exercising those rights is unreasonable and has resulted in injury to his adversary.Â  Id.Â  A determination of laches rests within the sound discretion of the trial court and must be determined by the facts of each case.Â  Id.Â 
In this case, Pendleton informed Kassel of his intent to sue before any construction on Lot 12 began.Â  During the months that followed Kassel beginning construction of his house, Plaintiffs repeatedly attempted to contact the county zoning office, the Association, OCRM, and the Army Corps of Engineers to determine their rights in this matter.Â  When Plaintiffs were finally able to meet with county zoning officers, they addressed their issues with Kasselâ€™s construction plan, and the county issued a stop work order.Â  Once the Board rescinded the stop work order on appeal, Plaintiffs diligently filed their complaint the next morning.Â  Under the facts of this case, we find Plaintiffsâ€™ delay to be reasonable.Â  
IV.Â  Adjudicating Kasselâ€™s Rights Against Georgetown County
Kassel contends the trial court erred in not addressing Plaintiffsâ€™ appeal from the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for review. Â 
One party may not â€˜bootstrapâ€™ or benefit from another partyâ€™s objection or challenge.Â  See Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 324 n.3, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 n.3 (1997). When the circuit court does not specifically address an issue, and when an issue presented to the circuit court in a civil case is not explicitly ruled upon in the final order, the issue must be raised by an appropriate post-trial motion to be preserved for appellate review.Â  Summersell v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Public Safety, 337 S.C. 19, 22, 522 S.E.2d 144, 145-46 (1999).Â  Â 
Kassel was successful in his appeal to the Board seeking rescission of the stop work order; thus he did not appeal its decision to the trial court.Â  The appeal of the Boardâ€™s order rightfully came from the aggrieved parties, the Plaintiffs.Â  In the interest of judicial economy, the trial court incorporated Plaintiffsâ€™ appeal from the Boardâ€™s order into Plaintiffsâ€™ civil suit against Kassel.Â  After finding in favor of Plaintiffs and ordering Kassel to remove all structures within thirty feet of the bulkhead and permanently enjoining him from building in that area, the trial court properly dismissed Plaintiffsâ€™ appeal of the Boardâ€™s order as moot.Â  
Kassel is attempting to â€œbootstrapâ€ his appeal to this court based on Plaintiffsâ€™ appeal of the Boardâ€™s decision to the trial court.Â  This simply cannot be done.Â  Kassel neither raised this issue at trial nor in his motion for reconsideration; thus, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court properly enjoined Kassel from building within thirty feet of his rear property line, ordered Kassel to remove all permanent structures located within thirty feet of his rear property line, and dismissed Plaintiffsâ€™ appeal of the Boardâ€™s decision as moot.Â  Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.  
 KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.  

[1] â€œFlag Lotsâ€ simply refers to the irregular flag shape of the lots.Â  Flag lots are â€œreal wide on one side and very narrow on the other.â€Â  Kassel and Dozier had to configure the lots irregularly because in order for a home to be built on a lot in Georgetown County, the lot must contain 10,000 square feet or more and contain a sufficient â€œenvelopeâ€ in which to build.Â  
[2] The â€œbulkheadâ€ in this case is a retaining wall built along the waterfront; it sits very near the rear property line of Lot 12.
[3]Â  Dozier was named as a party based on his prior ownership of Lots 11 and 12 and the fact that he was acting as Kasselâ€™s builder in the construction of the house on Lot 12.Â  
[4]Â  The Association informed the court that it did not wish to participate in the trial.Â  The Association believed no specific relief was sought against it, and its position would be adequately represented by the other parties.Â  They agreed to be bound by the courtâ€™s decision.Â  
[5] Â Even if Kassel legally owned the cypress flats, his use of this land to satisfy the setback requirements for the construction on Lot 12 would be inappropriate because Lot 12 and the cypress flats constitute two separate lots.Â  Kassel would have had to file a new plat with the county and been permitted to join the two lots.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        City of Beaufort, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
          Eddie Holcombe, Appellant.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4134
  Submitted June 1, 2006 – Filed July 10, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Scott Wayne Lee, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
        William B. Harvey and Caroline Meng, both of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.: Â The Municipal Court of the City of Beaufort convicted Eddie Holcombe of failing to obtain a business license in violation of section 7-1001 of the Beaufort Municipal Code.Â  Holcombe appealed to the circuit court, which upheld the conviction.Â  Holcombe again appeals, arguing the Cityâ€™s ordinance violates the Equal Protection Clauses of our federal and state constitutions.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
At the time of this action, Holcombe owned a commercial building in downtown Beaufort that was divided into multiple offices.Â  Holcombe operated his own optometry business (a professional association) in one of the offices.Â  In addition, he received rental income from an unrelated, commercial tenant occupying another office within the building.[2]Â  Holcombe admittedly paid no business license fee related to the rental of commercial property to either of these businesses.Â Â Â  
On August 14, 2003, the City of Beaufort cited Holcombe for violation of section 7-1001, which requires all persons engaged in any business, service, occupation, or profession classified by the City to obtain a business license and pay an annual license fee.[3]Â  The City contended Holcombe, as a commercial landlord, should have obtained a business license and paid fees based on the rental income generated from the property he leased to the third party.Â  Although not expressly provided for in the ordinance, the City exempts a landlord from the license fee requirements when the landlord occupies rental property for his own use or pays rent to himself.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In October 2003, the Municipal Court of the City of Beaufort found Holcombe guilty of failing to obtain a business license.Â  Acting Municipal Judge James A. Grimsley, III noted that under the Beaufort Municipal Code, a license was required for â€œ[l]essors of non-residential buildings (with gross rental income of $12,000.00 or more).â€[4]Â  The judge found Holcombe was the owner of real property in Beaufort and he had failed to obtain an annual business license based on the rental income he received on the property for the years 2000, 2001, and 2002.[5]Â  Holcombe was sentenced to thirty days in jail, suspended upon the payment of a $750.00 fine plus all amounts due under the ordinance, to include administrative penalties for nonpayment as may be provided for in the ordinance.Â Â Â  
On appeal, Holcombe challenged the constitutionality of the Cityâ€™s application of the ordinance.Â  Specifically, he contested the Cityâ€™s determination that a property owner who leases property to himself (or an entity wholly owned by him) is not in the business of leasing so as to require the payment of a business license fee, whereas a property owner who leases property to third parties is in business and thus required to pay a business license fee.Â  Holcombe argued the Cityâ€™s unwritten exemption for property owners who rented to themselves (or their alter-egos) violated his equal protection rights.Â  Â Â 
The Equal Protection Clauses of our federal and state constitutions declare that no person shall be denied the equal protection of the laws.[6]Â  This â€œsimply means that no person, or class of persons, shall be denied the same protection of the laws which is enjoyed by other persons or other classes in the same place and under like circumstances.â€[7]Â  Â Â 

In evaluating whether an enactment affords equal protection, we must first decide what level of scrutiny to apply.[8]Â  â€œCourts generally analyze equal protection challenges under one of three standards: Â (1) rational basis; (2) intermediate scrutiny; or, (3) strict scrutiny.â€[9]Â  â€œIf the classification does not implicate a suspect class or abridge a fundamental right, the rational basis test is used.â€[10]Â  Inherently suspect classifications include those based on factors â€œsuch as race, religion, or alienage.â€[11]Â 
In this instance, we agree with the circuit courtâ€™s determination that â€œlandlords do not constitute a â€˜suspectâ€™ class, [so] the â€˜rational basisâ€™ test is used.â€[12]Â  â€œTo satisfy the equal protection clause, a classification must (1) bear a reasonable relation to the legislative purpose sought to be achieved, (2) members of the class must be treated alike under similar circumstances, and (3) the classification must rest on some rational basis.â€[13]Â Â Â  Â Â 
Equal Protection Clauses are subject to a wide scope of discretion and legislative enactments are to be avoided only when they are without any reasonable basis.[14]Â  Only â€œirrational and unjustified classificationsâ€ are barred.[15] Â 
â€œA municipal ordinance is a legislative enactment and is presumed to be constitutional.â€[16] â€œThe burden is upon the taxpayer to prove unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt.â€[17]Â  The burden requires the attacker to negate every conceivable basis that might support it.[18]Â  The reasonableness of an ordinance is a question of law for the court to decide unless there is a controversy about the facts of the case, which must be decided by a jury.[19]Â Â Â  
In the current case, the City imposes a business license fee on â€œ[l]essors of non-residential buildings (with gross rental income of $12,000.00 or more).â€Â  Thus, the City has created two classes of commercial landlords:Â  (1) those utilizing commercial property for their own businesses, so that those businesses are their source of income, and (2) those who are renting property to third parties, so that the rental fees generated are their source of income.Â  
In finding these two groups are not similarly situated and upholding the Cityâ€™s imposition of a business license fee on Holcombeâ€™s rental income, Special Circuit Court Judge Curtis L. Coltrane reasoned as follows:

  A business owner who rents his own property to himself is not in the business of renting property, but rather is in whatever business he operates from within the property.Â  The business/property owner does not offer his property for rent in the general market.Â  The business owner pays a business license fee on the business he actually operates.Â  A commercial landlord, on the other hand, operates no business from within the property he leases, and pay[s] no business license fee on the businesses operated from within the property.Â  The commercial landlord does pay a business license fee on the business he actually operates, that being the leasing of real property on the open market.Â  

We agree with the circuit courtâ€™s reasoning and conclude there is a rational and reasonable basis for the Cityâ€™s classifications.Â  As noted by the circuit court, a property owner who uses commercial property for his own business is not in the â€œbusinessâ€ of renting commercial property, but rather, is in whatever business he actually operates on the property.Â  In this case, Holcombe operated an optometry business on the premises he actually occupied.Â  On the other hand, a property owner renting commercial property to third parties is in the business of renting commercial property.Â  Commercial landlords renting to third parties, as a class, are treated alike and equally in these circumstances.[20]Â  Based on the foregoing, we hold the challenged ordinance as applied is not plainly arbitrary and does not violate Holcombeâ€™s equal protection rights.[21]Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur.

[1] We decide this appeal without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  In his brief, Holcombe states the building is divided into two offices and he rents the second office to an unrelated business.Â  The City asserts Holcombe â€œreceives substantial rental income from the multiple commercial tenants within the building.â€Â  
[3] Â â€œEvery person engaged, or intending to engage in any calling, business, service, activity, occupation or profession listed in the rate classification portion of this chapter, in whole or in part, within the limits of the city, is required to pay an annual license fee and obtain a business license as herein provided.â€Â  Beaufort Municipal Code, Ordinance Â§ 7-1001(a).Â  
[4]Â  This specific language does not appear in any portion of the ordinance appearing in the Record on Appeal, but the parties do not dispute its application here and raise no issue in this regard on appeal.
[5]Â  The judge applied a three-year statute of limitations.Â  
[6] Â U.S. Const. amend. XIV, Â§ 1; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 3.Â  
[7] Â Harrison v. Caudle, 141 S.C. 407, 416, 139 S.E. 842, 845 (1927).
[8] Â In re Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. 122, 147, 568 S.E.2d 338, 351 (2002).
[9] Denene, Inc. v. City of Charleston, 359 S.C. 85, 91, 596 S.E.2d 917, 920 (2004); see also Clark v. Jeter, 486 U.S. 456, 461 (1988); 19 S.C. Juris. Constitutional Law Â§ 85 (1993).
[10] Denene, 359 S.C. at 91, 596 S.E.2d at 920; see also Hendrix v. Taylor, 353 S.C. 542, 549, 579 S.E.2d 320, 323 (2003).
[11] Sunset Cay, LLC v. City of Folly Beach, 357 S.C. 414, 429, 593 S.E.2d 462, 469 (2004).
[12] Cf. Fraternal Order of Police v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 352 S.C. 420, 574 S.E.2d 717 (2002) (applying rational basis standard, not heightened scrutiny, to equal protection challenge of revenue statutes dealing with bingo).
[13] Sunset Cay, 357 S.C. at 428, 593 S.E.2d at 469.
[14] Ward v. Town of Darlington, 183 S.C. 263, 274, 190 S.E. 826, 831 (1937).
[15] In re Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. at 147, 568 S.E.2d at 351.
[16] Town of Scranton v. Willoughby, 306 S.C. 421, 422, 412 S.E.2d 424, 425 (1991).
[17] Id.
[18] Id.
[19] Ward, 183 S.C. at 270, 190 S.E. at 829.
[20] See Ed Robinson Laundry & Dry Cleaning, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 356 S.C. 120, 124, 588 S.E.2d 97, 99 (2003) (â€œA class may be constitutionally confined to a particular trade.â€); Pee Dee Chair Co. v. City of Camden, 165 S.C. 86, 162 S.E. 771 (1932) (stating â€œbusiness,â€ as used in ordinances requiring persons engaged in a â€œbusinessâ€ to obtain a license, implies continuity or custom).
[21] See Whaley v. Dorchester County Zoning Bd. of Appeals, 337 S.C. 568, 576, 524 S.E.2d 404, 408 (1999) (â€œThe determination of whether a classification is reasonable is initially one for the legislative body and will be sustained if it is not plainly arbitrary and there is any reasonable hypothesis to support it.â€); Eli Witt Co. v. City of West Columbia, 309 S.C. 555, 425 S.E.2d 16 (1992) (holding ordinance imposing business license tax upon the gross income of businesses did not contain an arbitrary classification where it exempted businesses paying a similar tax on that income to another city; all businesses paying a similar tax are treated alike and the classification is reasonably related to the purpose of avoiding duplicative taxation); see also Ponder v. City of Greenville, 196 S.C. 79, 12 S.E.2d 851 (1941) (noting legislation does not deny equal protection merely because it is specific or limited to a particular class and holding statute providing wholesalers delivering goods to retailers in any municipality shall not be charged a business license tax unless they maintain a warehouse within the municipality is not arbitrary and capricious as those operating within the municipality receive advantages and for such privilege they should pay a license tax).
