THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Dan F. Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Middleton, Alfred C., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4135
Heard June 15, 2006 â€“ Filed July 10, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Desa A. Ballard, of W. Columbia, for Appellants.
        James C. Parham, Jr. and Patricia S. Ravenhorst, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Dan F. Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company (collectively, â€œWilliamsonâ€) appeal from the trial courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Alfred C. Middleton.Â  Williamson argues that Middleton is not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees, or in the alternative, that the criteria for awarding attorneyâ€™s fees were not met in this case.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
For several years, Middleton worked for Williamson as a commissioned salesman. Â When Middleton quit working for Williamson, he was due a commission for having sold yarn pallets to one of Williamsonâ€™s customers.Â  Middleton and Williamson disagreed as to the amount of commission due, and Williamson never paid Middleton any commission, even though it acknowledged owing him $906.62.Â  
After leaving his employment with Williamson, Middleton began working for Peninsula Plastics, Inc., one of Williamsonâ€™s pallet suppliers.Â  Middleton continued to seek the commission Williamson owed him, and sought assistance from his present attorney.Â  Middleton and his counsel are personal friends, and counsel previously had represented Middleton in less-complicated matters without charge.Â  Middletonâ€™s attorney agreed to help with the claim for commission, and the two were to discuss a fee at the end of the case. 
Williamson initially was represented by Jordan & Clardy, LLC.Â  Middletonâ€™s attorneys informed Williamson that they had a complaint drafted and were ready to sue in order to recover the unpaid commission.Â  Williamsonâ€™s attorney requested that Middleton refrain from acting on the drafted complaint until he could speak with his client.Â  Middleton agreed, and two days later, Williamson filed a complaint against Middleton, alleging causes of action for fraud, constructive fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act. Â Middleton filed an answer, denying the allegations and counterclaiming for commissions owed and sanctions under the South Carolina Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  Approximately one month prior to trial, Williamson hired its current counsel. 
Of Williamsonâ€™s claims against Middleton, only the cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty went to the jury.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Middleton on that cause of action and found in favor of Middleton on his counterclaim for unpaid commission, awarding him $906.62 in actual damages.Â  
The trial judge, Judge Pyle, ruled Middleton was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees, but asked the parties to attempt to determine the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees themselves.Â  In the event they could not agree to an amount, Judge Pyle explained he would set the amount for them.Â  The parties could not come to a consensus on the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees, and Middleton petitioned the court for assistance.Â  Judge Miller awarded Middleton $35,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In an unpublished opinion, Williamson v. Middleton, 2005-UP-011 (S.C. Ct. App. filed January 11, 2005), this Court found that Judge Pyle had retained exclusive jurisdiction over the matter.Â  We therefore reversed Judge Millerâ€™s award and remanded the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees for Judge Pyleâ€™s consideration. 
At the hearing before Judge Pyle, Williamson argued Middleton was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees because (1) he was not the prevailing party; (2) the bill Middletonâ€™s counsel presented documenting over $100,000 worth of work listed hours spent on claims other than the unpaid commission claim for which attorneyâ€™s fees are allowed; and (3) the amount of fees Middletonâ€™s counsel requested, $35,000, far exceeded the $906.62 verdict. Â Williamson further maintained Middleton did not incur any fees because when Middletonâ€™s counsel was deposed, he admitted there was no fee agreement between him and Middleton.Â  
Judge Pyle acknowledged that Middleton and his attorney had not entered into a formal, written fee agreement, but relied instead â€œon their long-standing personal relationship and mutual agreement to determine an appropriate fee for services at the conclusion of this matter.â€ Â The judge found such an agreement did not preclude attorneyâ€™s fees. Â Accordingly, Judge Pyle awarded Middleton $35,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Williamson filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, which was denied.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
There must be sufficient evidence in the record to support each of the six factors analyzed for an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  See Taylor v. Medenica, 331 S.C. 575, 580, 503 S.E.2d 458, 461 (1998).Â  â€œOn appeal, absent sufficient evidentiary support on the record for each factor, the award should be reversed and the issue remanded for the trial court to make specific findings of fact.â€Â  Blumberg v. Nealco, 310 S.C. 492, 494, 427 S.E.2d 659, 661 (1993).Â  
The interpretation of a statute is not a finding of fact.Â  Thompson v. Ford Motor Co., 200 S.C. 393, 21 S.E.2d 34 (1942).Â  â€œThe issue of interpretation of a statute is a question of law for the court.â€Â  Jeter v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., Op. No. 26168 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed June 19, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 23 at 43) (citing Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 459 S.E.2d (1991); see also Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 621, 611 S.E.2d 297, 301 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œThe determination of legislative intent is a matter of law.â€) (citations omitted); Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 417, 503 S.E.2d 191, 200 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œ[T]he interpretation of a statute is a matter of law.â€).Â  See, e.g., Carolina Power & Light Co. v. Town of Pageland, 321 S.C. 538, 471 S.E.2d 137 (1996); Byrd v. Irmo High School, 321 S.C. 426, 468 S.E.2d 861 (1996); Rowe v. Hyatt, 321 S.C. 366, 468 S.E.2d 649 (1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Williamson first argues Middleton is not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees because he does not meet the requirements of section 39-65-30 of the South Carolina Code.Â  Specifically, Williamson points out that this statute only applies to sales representatives who seek to recover commissions on â€œwholesaleâ€ sales, and the commission awarded to Middleton was from a sale made to the ultimate consumer.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review.
Initially, we note that the arguments Williamson made to Judge Pyle on this issue are not reflected in the record on appeal.Â  Williamson did not advance this argument at the hearing before Judge Pyle, and although Williamsonâ€™s counsel refers to a memorandum she filed in opposition to Middletonâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees, that memorandum was not included in the record on appeal.Â  See Taylor v. Taylor, 294 S.C. 296, 299, 363 S.E.2d 909, 911 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œThe burden is on the appellant to furnish a sufficient record on appeal from which this court can make an intelligent review.â€).Â  We acknowledge, however, that Judge Pyle addressed the argument in his order awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, suggesting the argument was set forth in Williamsonâ€™s memorandum.Â  In the order, Judge Pyle found Williamsonâ€™s argument that Middleton was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to section 39-65-30 came too late because during trial, Williamson never objected to the jury instructions referencing section 39-65-30, nor did Williamson challenge Judge Pyleâ€™s initial ruling that Middleton was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
In its brief to our court, Williamson argues that â€œ[e]ven though the jury returned a verdict . . . that awarded Middleton $906.62 for unpaid commissions, this recovery was sought on alternate grounds, both pursuant to Â§ 39-65-30 and Â§ 41-10-10.â€Â  In so arguing, Williamson implies the juryâ€™s award was based on a statute other than section 39-65-30.Â  Williamson further contends that its argument on this issue is timely because â€œthe request for attorney fees is predicated on entirely different factors than was the request for commissions.â€Â  From the record before us, there is no indication this specific argument was ever made to the trial court, either prior to the order awarding attorneyâ€™s fees or in Williamsonâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for review.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€); see also Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 73, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œâ€˜Imposing this preservation requirement on the appellant is meant to enable the lower court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and arguments.â€™â€) (quoting Iâ€™On, L.L.C v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000)); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 103, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œWithout an initial ruling by the trial court, a reviewing court simply would not be able to evaluate whether the trial court committed error.â€).
Next, Williamson argues Middleton failed to prove the elements necessary to recover fees.Â  We agree.
The general rule is that attorneyâ€™s fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.Â  Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc.,  310 S.C. 492, 493, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993) (citing Baron Data Sys., Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 377 S.E.2d 296 (1989); Hegler v. Gulf Ins. Co., 270 S.C. 548, 243 S.E.2d 443 (1978); Collins v. Collins, 239 S.C. 170, 122 S.E.2d 1 (1961)); accord Seabrook Island Property Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Berger, 365 S.C. 234, 238, 616 S.E.2d 431, 434 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œIn South Carolina, the authority to award attorneyâ€™s fees can come only from a statute or be provided for in the language of a contract.Â  There is no common law right to recover attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  Harris-Jenkins v. Nissan Car Mart, Inc., 348 S.C. 171, 176, 557 S.E.2d 708, 710 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 486 S.E.2d 750 (1997); American Fed. Bank, FSB v. Number One Main Joint Venture, 321 S.C. 169, 467 S.E.2d 439 (1996); Blumberg, 310 S.C. 492, 427 S.E.2d 659; Baron Data, 297 S.C. 382, 377 S.E.2d 296; Dowaliby v. Chambless, 344 S.C. 558, 544 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2001); Harvey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 338 S.C. 500, 527 S.E.2d 765 (Ct. App. 2000); Global Protection Corp. v. Halbersberg, 332 S.C. 149, 503 S.E.2d 483 (Ct. App. 1998); Prevatte v. Asbury Arms, 302 S.C. 413, 396 S.E.2d 642 (Ct. App. 1990)).
Section 39-65-30 provides:

  A principal who fails to comply with the provisions of Section 39-65-20 is liable to the sales representative in a civil action for:
  
    (1)Â  all amounts due the sales representative plus punitive damages in an amount not to exceed three times the amount of commissions due the sales representative; and
    (2)Â  attorneyâ€™s fees actually and reasonably incurred by the sales representative in the action and court costs.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-30 (Supp. 2005).Â  The jury awarded Middleton the unpaid commission pursuant to section 39-65-20.Â  Therefore, we are dealing with a statutory attorneyâ€™s fee provision.Â  
 When awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, the trial court must consider the following six factors: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the legal services rendered; (2) the time and labor necessarily devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the fee customarily charged in the locality for similar legal services; and (6) the beneficial results obtained.Â  Baron Data, 297 S.C. at 384-85, 377 S.E.2d at 297.Â  When awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, â€œthere is no requirement that [the fees] be less than or comparable to a partyâ€™s monetary judgment.â€Â  Taylor v. Medenica, 331 S.C. 575, 580, 503 S.E.2d 458, 461 (1998).
Here, Middleton incurred no attorneyâ€™s fees because no fee agreement existed between Middleton and his attorney.Â  In his deposition, Middletonâ€™s lead counsel stated:

  [W]e donâ€™t have a fee agreement with Mr. Middleton.Â  We talked about this with Mr. Middleton to begin with and we decided that we would try to help him collect the monies due him and at the end of the case, we would talk about a fee.Â  So we donâ€™t have a fee agreement with him. Â But some day, he might pay us a fee.Â  Right now, he has no obligation at this point if there is no agreement.Â  He might feel a moral obligation.Â  And when we talk at the end of the case, he will have the final say.

(Emphasis added.)Â  
Counselâ€™s testimony admits there was no fee agreement with Middleton.Â  Consequently, there is no obligation to pay, and no fees have been incurred.
Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 540 S.E.2d 454 (2000), involved Fatherâ€™s action to recover overpayment of child support and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The court found Father was entitled to reimbursement of child support overpayments, but held he could not recover attorneyâ€™s fees because his current wife represented him and they did not have a fee agreement.Â  The court began its analysis by noting that Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 529 S.E.2d 14 (2000), held a pro se litigant could not recover attorneyâ€™s fees because â€œa pro se litigant, whether an attorney or layperson, does not become â€˜liable for or subject to fees charged by an attorney.â€™â€Â  343 S.C. at 306, 540 S.E.2d at 457.Â  The Hopkins court declared:

  [H]ere, we find no evidence Father actually became â€œliable for or subject toâ€ attorneysâ€™ fees for his attorney/wifeâ€™s service.Â  There is no contract or fee agreement in the record, nor is there any indication or testimony that Fatherâ€™s wife/attorney has attempted or intends to collect the fees from Father. Â Accordingly, Father did not prove that he became liable for the fees, such that the family court properly denied Fatherâ€™s request.

343 S.C. at 307, 540 S.E.2d at 457.Â  
The rationale of Hopkins is equally applicable in the instant case.Â  Both Calhoun and Hopkins focused on the litigantsâ€™ lack of liability for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Here, Middletonâ€™s counsel admits Middleton â€œhas no obligation at this point if there is no agreement.â€Â  There is no agreement; therefore, Middleton owes no obligation to pay, and no fees were incurred.Â  Under these facts the trial judge erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Because we reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees on this ground, we need not address Williamsonâ€™s arguments that Middleton was not the prevailing party and that the fees awarded were unreasonable.
CONCLUSION
We hold that in South Carolina there must be an agreement between counsel and client in order for a court to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In the case sub judice, there is unequivocally no agreement to pay attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the award of fees is 
REVERSED.
CURETON, A.J., concurs.
HEARN, C.J., dissents in a separate opinion.
HEARN, C.J.: Because I believe a party can recover attorneyâ€™s fees absent a formal agreement, I respectfully disagree with the majorityâ€™s reversal of the $35,000 award of fees to Middleton.Â  It is well-settled that â€œ[w]here an attorneyâ€™s services and their value are determined by the trier of fact, an appeal will not prevail if the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€Â  Baron Data Sys. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 384, 377 S.E.2d 296, 296 (1989) (emphasis added).Â  Here, there is evidence supporting the trial courtâ€™s determination that Middleton and his attorneys had an informal agreement to â€œdetermine an appropriate fee for services at the conclusion of this matter.â€Â  Therefore, I vote to affirm.Â  
As the majority points out, Middletonâ€™s lead counsel stated in his deposition: 

  [W]e donâ€™t have a fee agreement with Mr. Middleton.Â  We talked about this with Mr. Middleton to begin with and we decided that we would try to help him collect the monies due him and at the end of the case, we would talk about a fee.Â  So we donâ€™t have a fee agreement with him. But some day, he might pay us a fee.Â  Right now, he has no obligation at this point if there is no agreement.Â  He might feel a moral obligation.Â  And when we talk at the end of the case, he will have the final say.

(Emphasis added.)Â  While this testimony could be interpreted to mean Middleton would never be required to pay a fee, it also indicates that Middleton and his attorneys would discuss a fee at the end of the case.Â Â  The trial judge adopted this latter interpretation, and based on our standard of review, I do not believe we can second-guess his conclusion.[1]Â  
Because there was testimony evidencing counselâ€™s intent to discuss a fee with Middleton, I believe this case is easily distinguished from Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 540 S.E.2d 454 (2000).Â  In Hopkins, the supreme court upheld the family courtâ€™s determination that Husband was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees when he was represented at trial by his attorney/wife.Â  In so doing, the supreme court did not merely rely on a lack of a fee agreement, but also stressed there was no â€œindication or testimony that [appellantâ€™s] wife/attorney intends to collect the fees from [appellant].â€Â  Id. at 307, 540 S.E.2d at 457.Â  Here, there was evidence Middleton and his attorney would discuss fees at the conclusion of the case.Â  
The majority finds Middleton did not incur any attorneyâ€™s fees because he and his attorneys did not have a fee agreement.Â  However, the lack of a formal fee agreement does not preclude an attorney from collecting fees.Â  See Singleton v. Collins, 251 S.C. 208, 210-11, 161 S.E.2d 246, 247 (1968) (â€œAn attorney has a right to be paid for professional services rendered, and where there is no express contract, the law will imply one.â€).Â  Although the Singleton case is procedurally different from the case at hand, its determination regarding attorneyâ€™s fees is instructive.Â  In Singleton, an attorney filed an action to collect fees after rendering services to a client in a domestic relations action.Â  Despite the lack of a formal contract, the trial court implied a contract and determined the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees owed.Â  Our supreme court upheld the trial courtâ€™s decision, noting: â€œWhether the services were rendered, and their value, are matters of fact to be decided . . . by the court below, and no appeal lies therefrom if the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€Â  Id. at 211, 161 S.E.2d at 247.
Although Singleton involves the collection of attorneyâ€™s fees from a client rather than an opposing party, it illustrates that the lack of a formal agreement is not fatal to an attorneyâ€™s claim for fees.Â  Here, the trial judge was not precluded from awarding attorneyâ€™s fees simply because Middleton and his attorneys lacked a written agreement.Â  Rather, so long as there was evidence Middletonâ€™s attorneys intended to collect a fee, the trial judge had discretion to award the fee.Â  Not only did Judge Pyle find there was such evidence, but Judge Miller, whose ruling was reversed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, found an informal agreement existed as well.Â  Because there is evidence in the record to support the findings of these two outstanding trial judges, I vote to affirm their determination that a fee had been incurred. 
In addition to its argument that Middleton did not incur attorneyâ€™s fees, Williamson also argues Middleton failed to prove the other elements necessary to recover fees, or in the alternative, that the fees awarded were unreasonably high.Â  I disagree.
When awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, the trial court must consider the following six factors: (1) the nature, extent and difficulty of the legal services rendered; (2) the time and labor necessarily devoted to the case; (3) the professional standing of counsel; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the fee customarily charged in the locality for similar legal services; and (6) the beneficial results obtained.Â  Baron Data Sys, Inc., v. Loter, 297 S.C. at 384-85, 377 S.E.2d at 297.Â  â€œWhere an attorneyâ€™s services and their value are determined by the trier of fact, an appeal will not prevail if the findings of fact are supported by any competent evidence.â€Â  Id. at 384, 377 S.E.2d at 296 (emphasis added).Â  Here, Judge Pyle made specific findings on each of the six elements, and there is evidence in the record supporting those findings.Â  
Williamson also argues that even if we find Middleton was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees, the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees awarded was unreasonable in light of the beneficial results Middleton received.Â  However, â€œthere is no requirement that attorneyâ€™s fees be less than or comparable to a partyâ€™s monetary judgment.â€Â  Taylor v. Medenica, 331 S.C. 575, 580, 503 S.E.2d 458, 461 (1998).Â  Furthermore, although a $35,000 attorneyâ€™s fee may initially seem high for a cause of action for unpaid commissions, especially when the action resulted in a $906.62 verdict, under the peculiar circumstances of this case, there was evidence in the record supporting the trial judgeâ€™s finding that $35,000 was a reasonable amount to award.Â  First and foremost, it is important to note that Middletonâ€™s attorney did not institute this lawsuit.Â  Rather, in the best tradition of the profession, he attempted to settle this matter with Williamson, and at the specific request of opposing counsel, Middleton delayed bringing suit.Â  However, within a matter of days, Williamson filed suit against Middleton.Â  In order to litigate his cause of action for unpaid commissions, Middleton had to defend himself against Williamsonâ€™s claim against him for breach of fiduciary duty, which is an affirmative defense for unpaid commissions.Â  Additionally, Middleton submitted affidavits demonstrating how Williamson employed dilatory tactics prior to the trial of this case, such as persuading Middleton to withhold from filing its complaint so that it could be the first file a complaint, cancelling depositions on the afternoon before or the morning of their scheduled time, and submitting incomplete responses to Middletonâ€™s requests for discovery.[2] Based on the detailed bills submitted by Middletonâ€™s attorneys and the difficulties they faced in trying their case, I find competent evidence supports the trial judgeâ€™s award of $35,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, I vote to affirm the trial courtâ€™s order.

[1] If the trial judge had refused to award Middleton fees in the present case, I would vote to affirm that determination also, as there is evidence in the record to support it.Â  
[2] Williamsonâ€™s current counsel was not yet involved in this case when the complaint was filed, nor was she involved when these pre-trial delays occurred.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Diane Ardis & William David Ardis, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Edward L. Sessions, D.C., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4136
Heard October 6, 2005 â€“ Filed July 10, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Ellis I. Kahn and Justin S. Kahn, both of Charleston, for Appellants.
        Charles E. Hill and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this appeal of a chiropractic malpractice action, Diane B. Ardis and William David Ardis raise issues concerning the exclusion of evidence, jury instructions, and the trial courtâ€™s refusal to strike the cross-examination of Diane Ardisâ€™s treating physician based on ex parte contact with the opposing side.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
In their complaint filed June 1, 2001, Diane and William Ardis (collectively â€œArdisâ€) alleged that Edward L. Sessions negligently injured Diane by performing spinal manipulations on February 19, 1996.Â  Ardis claims Sessionsâ€™s negligence caused a ruptured or herniated disk in Dianeâ€™s back, an increase in the severity of her initial injury, and ultimately the need for back surgery.Â  Sessions denied that he performed a manipulation on that date.Â  His notes indicate Dianeâ€™s disk was herniated when she fell from a ladder prior to coming to his office on February 19.[1]Â  At trial, Sessions testified that instead of a manipulation that day, he used a less invasive treatment, which would have been insufficient to herniate Dianeâ€™s disk. 
At an in camera hearing, Sessions, who served as a municipal court judge for the City of Hanahan, moved to prevent Ardis from making an inquiry into his public reprimand by the South Carolina Supreme Court. In 2000, the Sessions was reprimanded for acts of judicial misconduct, which included making and directing the making of false entries in judicial records.Â  See In re Sessions, 342 S.C. 427, 538 S.E.2d 1 (2000).Â  Sessions also moved in limine to exclude any mention of his billing practices in regard to his different fee schedules for individuals and insurance carriers.Â  The trial court granted Sessionsâ€™s motions.
At trial, Ardis objected to the following instructions given by the trial court regarding the applicable standard of care: [2]

  The law does not require of him absolute accuracy either in his practice or his judgment . . . It does not even require of him the utmost degree of care and skill of which the human mind is capable. 
  I instruct you that a physician is not an insurer of a cure or even of a beneficial result; thus, the mere fact that a treatment is not beneficial or that it is even harmful will not of itself raise a presumption of negligence . . . I instruct you that a bad result of the failure to cure is not by itself insufficient to raise an inference or a presumption of negligence on the part of a physician.
  I charge you that a physician is not ordinarily liable for making an incorrect diagnosis where it is made in good faith and there is reasonable doubt as to the nature of the physical conditions involved or as to what should be done in accordance with recognized authority in good current practice or where it is made in good faith on observation of the patient. 

The jury returned a verdict for Sessions.Â  The trial court denied Ardisâ€™s motion for JNOV, or in the alternative for a new trial.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ardis contends the trial court erred in instructing the jury regarding the applicable standard of care for a medical malpractice claim.Â  Specifically, Ardis argues the instruction given by the trial court raised the standard to a subjective standard, meaning that Ardisâ€™s burden of proof would require a showing that any error of judgment was made in bad faith.Â  We agree. [3]
A trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina. Â Cohens v. Atkins, 333 S.C. 345, 349, 509 S.E.2d 286, 289 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œThe substance of the law is what must be instructed to the jury, not any particular verbiage.Â  . . .Â  A jury charge which is substantially correct and covers the law does not require reversal.â€ Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 391, 574 S.E.2d 215, 220 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, the appellate court must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial. Â Daves v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 224, 584 S.E.2d 423, 427 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œWhere a request to charge is timely made and involves a controlling legal principle, a refusal by the trial judge to charge the request constitutes reversible error.â€Â  Koutsogiannis v. BB&T, 365 S.C. 145, 149, 616 S.E.2d 425, 427-28 (2005).Â  To warrant reversal for refusal to give a requested instruction, the refusal must have not only been erroneous, but prejudicial as well.Â  Cohens, 333 S.C. at 349, 509 S.E.2d at 289; see also Daves, 355 S.C. at 224, 584 S.E.2d at 427 (stating a circuit courtâ€™s refusal to give a properly requested charge is reversible error only when the requesting party can demonstrate prejudice from the refusal).
The instructions given in the instant case are very similar to those addressed in the case of McCourt by and through McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 457 S.E.2d 603 (1995).Â  In that case, McCourt, through the personal representative of her estate, filed a medical malpractice action against a doctor in connection with her death from sepsis.Â  The defendant argued the trial court erred in refusing to instruct the jury as follows:Â  

  When a physician exercises ordinary care and skill in keeping within recognized and proven methods, he is not liable for the result of a bona fide mistake in judgment.Â  
  A physician is not ordinarily liable for making an incorrect diagnosis where it is made in good faith and there is reasonable doubt as to the nature of the physical condition involved or as to what should be done in accordance with recognized authority and good current practice, or where it is made in good faith observation of a patient.Â  
  A physician cannot be held liable for a mere error in judgment.Â  
  When a physician exercises ordinary care and skill in keeping with recognized and proven methods he is not liable for the result of a mere mistake of judgment or for a bad result which does not occur because of any negligence on his part.

McCourt, 318 S.C. at 306, 457 S.E.2d at 606.Â  
In affirming the refusal to give the charge requested, the supreme court stated that such a jury instruction impermissibly implied â€œto the jury that an error in judgment is actionable only if made in bad faith.â€Â  Id. at 306, 457 S.E.2d at 606.Â  The court reasoned that this would â€œimpose an unrealistic burden on the plaintiff to prove the doctorâ€™s judgment was rendered with less than good faith.â€Â  Id.Â  
Like the proposed instruction in McCourt, the trial courtâ€™s instruction in this case impermissibly implied to the jury that any error in judgment by Sessions would be actionable only if rendered in bad faith.Â  Such an implication prejudiced Ardis because it imposed the same â€œunrealistic burdenâ€ disapproved of in McCourt. 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
REVERSED and REMANDED.
SHORT, J. concurs.
BEATTY, J. dissents in a separate opinion.Â  
BEATTY, J. (dissenting): I respectfully dissent.Â  When reviewing a jury instruction for alleged error, the appellate court must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  Davis v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 224, 584 S.E.2d 423, 427 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œIf the charge is reasonably free from error, isolated portions which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  Id.
The majority rests its decision on a comparison of a small portion of the trial courtâ€™s instructions to a substantial part of the requested instructions in McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 457 S.E.2d 603 (1995).Â  
In McCourt, the trial courtâ€™s decision not to give requested instructions was affirmed.Â  Although the court did not identify any specific offending jury charge requested, the court noted that the requested charges may be confusing to the jury.Â  The court stated, â€œSome of the charges imply to the jury that an error in judgment is actionable only if made in bad faith.Â  Such an instruction would impose an unrealistic burden on the plaintiff to prove the doctorâ€™s judgment was rendered in less than good faith.â€Â  McCourt, 318 S.C. at 306, 457 S.E.2d at 606.Â  Although the phrase â€œgood faithâ€ was used in a requested charge on making a diagnosis, the phrase was never actually used in an â€œerror in judgmentâ€ charge in McCourt.Â  Rather, a specific charge on â€œerror in judgmentâ€ implied that bad faith was required to find the doctor liable.[4]Â  In my view, the McCourt decision is based upon the full consideration of the jury instructions in total, not the mere use of the phrase â€œgood faith.â€Â  
Although similar, in part, the jury instruction here is significantly different from McCourt.Â  Here, the trial courtâ€™s â€œerror in judgmentâ€ charge stated:

  I further charge you that when there is more than one recognized method of treatment, the physician is at liberty to follow any such recognized treatment.Â  There may be more than one school of thought as to the proper treatment for a particular illness.Â  In cases where there is a difference of opinion between competent medical authorities, a physician will not be liable if, in the exercise of his judgment, he followed a course of treatment supported by reputable, respectable and reasonable medical experts.

Moreover, considering the trial courtâ€™s instructions here as a whole, they are substantially correct, reasonably free of error, and do not tend to confuse the jury as to what is required to establish liability.Â  The trial court gave the following instruction:

  I instruct you that when a chiropractor undertakes to treat a patient, the law requires him to use reasonable care and diligence in the exercise of his skill and in the application of his learning to accomplish the purpose for which he was employed.Â  The chiropractor is required by law to use his best judgment in exercising his skill and applying his knowledge.Â  And the law would, therefore, hold a chiropractor liable for any injury to his patient resulting from want or lack of the requisite or required knowledge or skill or the omission to exercise reasonable care or the failure to use his best judgment.Â  Therefore, a chiropractorâ€™s duty in treating his patients is to be measured by both his skill and diligence.
  If, by lack of the required skill, a chiropractor fails to properly treat his patient so that the patient is injured thereby or his condition is made worse than it would have been otherwise, then the chiropractor would be liable for any injury proximately caused to the patient.Â  He would also be liable if having the required or requisite skill, he negligently fails to use it or if he is not as careful and diligent in the treatment to the extent that he should be, which is to say as careful and diligent as a physician of ordinary prudence would have been under the same circumstances.
  In a case such as this, negligence is the failure to do that which an ordinarily, careful and prudent chiropractor would do under the same circumstances; or, it is the doing of that which an ordinarily prudent chiropractor would not have done under the existing circumstances.
  Negligence on the part of a chiropractor is not presumed, but must be affirmatively proved.Â  I told you earlier that the burden of proof was on the plaintiffs to prove their case by the preponderance or the greater weight of the evidence.Â  In the absence of evidence to the contrary, it will be presumed that a chiropractor has fully discharged his duty to the patient.Â  
  The burden of proof of negligence, proximate cause and injury in a malpractice case is on the plaintiff throughout.Â  In order to establish liability in a malpractice case, the plaintiff must prove by a preponderance of the evidence the following things:Â  what the recognized and generally accepted standards, practices and procedures which would be exercised by competent chiropractors under similar circumstances: the physician in question Â negligently deviated from the generally accepted standards practices and procedures; such negligent deviation from the generally accepted standards, practices and procedures was a proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injury; and that the plaintiff was injured.
  I instruct you that a physician is not an insurer of a cure or even of a beneficial result; thus, the mere fact that a treatment is not beneficial or that it is even harmful will not of itself raise a presumption of negligence.
  Injury and suffering are not alone sufficient to support a cause of action for malpractice unless it is shown by the greater weight of the evidence that the physician did not possess the degree of skill common to other physicians or that he failed to use such skill in the treatment of the patient. 
  I instruct you that a bad result or the failure to cure is not by itself sufficient to raise an inference or a presumption of negligence on the part of a physician.Â  Thus, if you find that the defendant in this case used due care and skill in treating the patient and that the physician followed recognized medical procedures and despite this, the patient suffered injuries, the fact of injury alone is not evidence of negligence and your verdict in such case should be for the defendant.
  I instruct you, Madame Forelady and members of the jury, that you are not permitted to arbitrarily set up a standard of your own in determining whether the defendantâ€™s learning skill and conduct fulfilled the duties imposed upon him by law.Â  The standard is that which I have already indicated, that is, did the chiropractor exercise that degree of knowledge, care and skill possessed by members of his specialty in good standing in the same or similar circumstances?
  I further charge you that when the opinions of medical experts are relied upon to establish causal connection of negligence to injury, the proper test to be applied is that the expert must, with reasonable certainty, state that, in his professional opinion, the injuries complained of most probably resulted from the alleged negligence of the defendant.
  Jurors are to apply the same standards of evaluation of expert witness testimony as applied to other witnesses.Â  It is for the jury to judge the credibility of the expert witnesses, as well as any other witnesses, and to decide what weight, if any, is attached to the expert testimony, as well as the testimony of any other witnesses.
  . . .
  I further charge you that in considering whether a physician has exercised reasonable judgment in a given case, you must consider such judgment in relationship to the facts as they existed at the time the judgment was made and not in light of what hindsight may reveal.
  I further charge you that a mistake in diagnosis of itself will not support a verdict in a malpractice suit.Â  I charge you that a physician is not ordinarily liable for making an incorrect diagnosis where it is made in good faith and there is reasonable doubt as to the nature of the physical conditions involved or as to what should be done in accordance with recognized authority in good current practice or where it is made in good faith on observation of the patient and based upon physical evidences and symptoms which would warrant such diagnosis by a reasonably prudent and informed physician.
  I further charge you that when there is more than one recognized method of treatment, the physician is at liberty to follow any such recognized treatment.Â  There may be more than one school of thought as to the proper treatment for a particular illness.Â  In cases where there is a difference of opinion between competent medical authorities, a physician will not be liable if, in the exercise of his judgment, he followed a course of treatment supported by reputable, respectable and reasonable medical experts.
  I charge you that the question of whether a physician in making a diagnosis deviated from applicable standard of care either by not employing a particular procedure or by not ordering a particular test, is to be determined by what an ordinary, careful and prudent physician would have done under the same or similar circumstances.
  I further charge you that the degree of skill and care a physician must use in diagnosing a condition is that which would be exercised by a competent practitioner in the defendant doctorâ€™s field of chiropractic.
  In order to find for the plaintiffs in a medical malpractice action, the plaintiff must show by the greater weight of the evidence that the physician did not possess the degree of skill common to other doctors in defendantâ€™s field of medicine, or that he failed or was negligent in so exercising such skills in the treatment of a patient.
  There must be a failure to do that which an ordinary, careful and prudent physician in the defendantâ€™s field of medicine would do under the same or similar circumstances shown by the evidence to have existed at the time of the transaction in question; or, it was the doing of that which an ordinary, careful and prudent physician in defendantâ€™s field of medicine would not have done under the same or similar circumstances known to have existed at the time of the transaction in question.

A jury charge which is substantially correct and covers the law does not require reversal.Â  Burroughs v. Worsham, 352 S.C. 382, 392, 574 S.E.2d 215, 220 (Ct. App. 2002).
I would affirm.

[1] Ardis claims that she received spinal manipulations merely to limber up for an upcoming ski trip and that she mentioned falling off of a ladder in jest.
[2] Ardis also objected to additional elements of the charge and requested an additional charge on spoliation of evidence.
[3] Because we reverse on this issue, we decline to address Ardisâ€™s remaining arguments.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (holding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when the resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).
[4] This charge provided:

  Request # 5:Â  A physician cannot be held liable for a mere error in judgment.Â  Where, according to standard medical practice, the diagnosis and course of treatment involved are matters to be subjected to the judgment of the physician, a physician must be allowed the exercise of that judgment and he cannot be held liable if in the exercise of the judgment he has made a mistake as to the course of treatment to be taken.

McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 456 S.E.2d 603, 606 (1995).

text:
Doe v. Barnwell School District


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jane Doe, by and through her legal guardian, and Robert Roe, by and through his legal guardian,[1]  Appellants,
v.
Barnwell School District 45 and Barnwell County Sheriffâ€™s Department, Defendants,
Of whom Barnwell School District 45 is, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Barnwell County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4137
Heard June 6, 2006 â€“ Filed July 17, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
R. Bentz Kirby and Glenn Walters, both of Orangeburg, for Appellants.Â  
Allen D. Smith, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Jane Doe and Robert Roe (the students) filed this action against Barnwell School District 45 and the Barnwell County Sheriffâ€™s Department alleging, inter alia, gross negligence in hiring and supervising personnel and resource officers.Â  The trial court dismissed the action against the district for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS[2]
The students attended Barnwell County High School.Â  During a football game on September 19, 2003, a police officer and a deputy sheriff discovered the students sitting in the back seat of an automobile parked on school grounds. Â Another deputy sheriff, who was a resource officer at the school, joined them at the car.Â  The police officer informed the deputies that he did not observe any inappropriate behavior or contact between the students.[3] Â The officer left the students in the care of the deputies.Â  The deputies questioned the students after escorting them to a school office.Â  The principal and two assistant principals were present and participated in the questioning. Â 
The students claim one of the deputies â€œattempted to intimidate and humiliate [Roe] by screaming, insulting, threatening, and other inappropriate language.â€Â  The studentsâ€™ parents were summoned to the school and informed their children had engaged in sexual activity while on school grounds.Â  As a result, Doeâ€™s parents took her to a hospital to undergo medical testing to determine if she had engaged in sexual intercourse.Â  The medical examination determined Doe had never engaged in sexual intercourse.Â  Although the principal initially threatened the students with expulsion or ten days suspension, she ultimately suspended them for only five days.Â  The students appealed the principalâ€™s decision to the school board, which upheld the suspension. Â 
The students then filed this action.Â  As to the district, the students alleged the principal failed to protect them and the district failed to properly train and supervise the principal and resource officers.Â  The trial court dismissed the suit against the district for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because it found the students were attempting to â€œcircumvent the prohibition against appealing short-term student suspensions . . . .â€Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[S]ubject matter jurisdiction is a question of law for the court.â€
Â Murphy v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 346 S.C. 37, 43, 550 S.E.2d 589, 592 (Ct. App. 2001), overruled on other grounds by Farmer v. Monsanto Corp., 353 S.C. 553, 579 S.E.2d 325 (2003).Â  Questions of law may be decided with no particular deference to the trial court.Â  Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 327, 534 S.E.2d 672, 675 (2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The students, contending their suit is based on gross negligence arising from the interrogation, argue the trial court erred in finding the lawsuit pertained to a school suspension and dismissing the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We agree.[4]
â€œSubject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Eagle Container Co. v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 633-34, 622 S.E.2d 733, 744 (Ct. App. 2005) (citation omitted).Â  In
Byrd v. Irmo High School, the supreme court found that South Carolina law does not provide for judicial review of student suspensions of ten days or less. Â 321 S.C. 426, 432-36, 468 S.E.2d 861, 864-67 (1996).Â  The court later qualified that holding to allow judicial review of a temporary suspension where the student challenges the suspension as violative of due process.Â 
Floyd v. Horry County Sch. Dist., 351 S.C. 233, 236-37, 569 S.E.2d 343, 345 (2002) (finding due process for students suspended ten days or less requires: Â (1) oral or written notice of the charges; (2) an explanation of the evidence; and (3) an opportunity to present their side of the story).
The trial court agreed with the districtâ€™s contention that the single reference in the claim to section 59-19-560 of the South Carolina Code as the basis for the trial courtâ€™s jurisdiction justifies characterizing the entire action as a challenge of the temporary suspensions.[5] Â Although this section appears to give the circuit court jurisdiction over appeals of suspensions, the court in Byrd found that the more recently enacted, specific statute, section 59-63-230, essentially superseded section 59-19-560 by providing for appeal to the board of trustees.Â  See 
Byrd, 321 S.C. at 434-35, 468 S.E.2d at 866; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-63-230 (2004).Â  Therefore, if this were solely an appeal of the suspension, the circuit court would lack jurisdiction.
In construing a complaint, however, the court must review the entire pleading.Â  Smith v. Nelson, 83 S.C. 294, 300, 65 S.E. 261, 263 (1909) (construing the â€œcomplaint upon the wholeâ€).Â  A review of the complaint as a whole in this case does not support the districtâ€™s argument that the students brought this action to appeal suspensions.Â  See Rule 8(f), SCRCP (providing that all pleadings must be construed to do substantial justice to all parties);
Gaskins v. S. Farm Bureau Cas. Ins. Co., 343 S.C. 666, 671, 541 S.E.2d 269, 271 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d as modified on other grounds, 354 S.C. 416, 581 S.E.2d 169 (2003) (â€œTo ensure substantial justice to the parties, the pleadings must be liberally construed.â€).Â  As stated in the complaint, the causes of action against the district are â€œGross Negligence and Gross Negligence in Hiring and Supervision.â€ Â The complaint does not request relief from the suspensions.Â  The suspensions merely arose out of the same situation as the alleged wrongful conduct by the district.Â  Unlike Floyd and Byrd, this case is based on the conduct of school officials and resource officers in the manner of interrogation and investigation rather than the wrongful imposition of suspensions.[6]  
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court erred in dismissing the action for lack of subject matter jurisdiction based solely on a finding that the action was an attempt to appeal short-term suspensions.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]  The names of the minor plaintiffs have been changed and the names of their guardians have been redacted to protect the minorsâ€™ identities.Â  
[2]  The facts related here are as alleged in the complaint.
[3]  The district contends the students were engaged in inappropriate sexual activity.Â  
[4]  Additionally, the students claim the trial court erred in failing to allow them to amend the complaint to remove a paragraph referencing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-19-560 (Rev. 2004).Â  Because we determine the trial court had jurisdiction over the complaint as it was written, determining whether the students should have been allowed to amend is unnecessary. 
[5]  Section 59-19-560 provides:Â  â€œAny party aggrieved by the order of the county board of education shall have the right to appeal to the court of common pleas . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-19-560 (Rev. 2004).Â  
[6]  At oral argument, the issue of the ultimate viability of this action was briefly mentioned.Â  We venture no opinion on the merits of this action.Â

title: Clay v. Burckle
description: Vacates the South Carolina Family Court order based on the finding that Florida retains jurisdiction of the custody proceedings pursuant to the provisions of both the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act and the Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act.
text:
Clay v. Burckle


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Judith Ann Burckle Clay, Appellant,
v.
Daryl James Burckle, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Peter R. Nuessle, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4138
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 17, 2006

VACATED


  
    
      
John L. Creson, of Augusta, for Appellant.Â  
Paul Andrew Anderson, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Judith Burckle Clay (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order naming Daryl Burckle (Father) primary residential parent of their son.Â  Mother argues South Carolina lacked jurisdiction over the matter because Florida still had exclusive jurisdiction under the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA) and the Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (PKPA).Â  We agree and vacate the order of the family court.[1]
FACTS
Mother and Father married on November 24, 1993, and had one child.Â  The family resided together in Florida until Mother and Father were granted a divorce by the Florida circuit court in 1997.Â  The divorce decree provided Mother and Father share parental responsibility for the child. Â The decree designated Mother as the primary residential parent and ordered that Father receive visitation.Â  Both parties remarried and continued to reside in Florida.Â  However, after several domestic disputes involving Mother and her new husband, the Juvenile Division of the Florida circuit court granted temporary custody to Father. Â Eventually, the court made Father the permanent, primary residential parent of the child and granted Mother supervised and telephone visitation.Â  
On July 23, 2002, Mother moved to establish unsupervised visitation, to address counseling for the child, and other related issues.Â  Additionally, on August 15, 2002, Mother filed a motion seeking to prevent the removal of the child from the jurisdiction of the Florida court.Â  On August 26, 2002, Father submitted a letter supplying the court with his new address and informing it that as of August 19, 2002, he lived in South Carolina.Â  
Thereafter, Mother filed a supplemental motion in the Florida court to modify custody or visitation.Â  The court found Father was to continue to serve as the primary residential parent, but Mother was to have unsupervised visitation with the child.Â  Mother traveled to South Carolina in an attempt to exercise visitation with the child for the Thanksgiving 2003 holiday, but she, even with assistance from South Carolina law enforcement officers, was unable to locate Father or the child.Â  
On December 17, 2003, Mother filed a motion for contempt in the Florida court seeking to compel Fatherâ€™s compliance with the courtâ€™s visitation order.Â  At the contempt hearing, Father appeared only through counsel.Â  The court issued an order finding Father to be in willful contempt of its previous order granting Mother visitation.Â  In support of its finding of contempt, the court found Father refused to allow visitation or any contact by telephone or mail. Â Further, the court found Father was incapable of performing his duties as primary residential parent, and the situations that caused Mother to lose custody no longer existed.Â  The circuit court ordered â€œas a sanction for [Fatherâ€™s] contemptuous conduct and pursuant to Florida Statute 61.13(4)(c)(5), [Mother] will hereafter be designated as the primary residential parent.â€Â  
Mother traveled to South Carolina to pick up the child as provided by the Florida courtâ€™s order, but Father would not allow her to take the child.Â  As a result, Mother filed an action in South Carolina family court to enforce the Florida courtâ€™s order making her the primary residential parent.Â  The South Carolina family court held a hearing and issued a bench order for the sheriff to locate the child and place him in the custody of Mother.Â  Father refused to turn the child over, obtained a new attorney, and filed a motion in the South Carolina family court to reconsider, alter, or amend the previous order requiring him to relinquish custody.Â  
On August 31, 2004, the South Carolina family court held a hearing on Fatherâ€™s motion.Â  In addition, it held an emergency hearing regarding the custody of the child.Â  The court issued its order finding the Florida court did not have jurisdiction over the child because South Carolina was the home state of the child at the time Mother brought the last custody related action in Florida.Â  The South Carolina family court vacated its previous order and declared it would not follow the Florida circuit court order that awarded Mother custody.Â  In a separate order, the family court awarded Father custody of the child and ordered the child not be removed from South Carolina.Â  Additionally, the South Carolina court found Mother was entitled to supervised visitation as she and Father could agree.Â  It is that order we address on appeal.
In the meantime, Father appealed to the Florida District Court of Appeals the Florida trial courtâ€™s order changing custody to Mother.Â  The Florida appellate court agreed with Fatherâ€™s argument that the Florida trial court erred in changing custody to Mother because she did not ask for that relief and reversed that portion of the trial courtâ€™s order but affirmed the finding of contempt.Â  The Florida appellate court remanded the case to the trial court for it to â€œfashion a suitable sanction for the contempt.â€ Â 
Mother then sought to supplement the record on appeal in our court to include the Florida appellate courtâ€™s opinion, prompting the response from Father that he would not contest its inclusion if the decision of the trial court on remand would also be included in the supplement to the record.Â  This court granted the motion to supplement the record with both the appellate courtâ€™s opinion and the circuit courtâ€™s order on remand.Â  
In the order on remand, the Florida trial court adamantly reasserted its exclusive jurisdiction and ordered Father to continue as primary residential parent with specified unsupervised visitation for Mother over various holidays and school breaks, together with other electronic and telephonic methods of visitation. Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother appeals the South Carolina family courtâ€™s order denying her custody and mandating supervised visitation â€œas agreeable between the parties.â€Â  Mother argues the South Carolina family court lacked jurisdiction to issue such an order in this custody matter under the PKPA, 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A (2000) and the UCCJA, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-782 to -830 (1976).Â  We agree.[2]
The PKPA and UCCJA â€œgovern the subject matter jurisdiction of state courts to rule in interstate custody disputes. Â Because the PKPA is federal legislation, its provisions will govern any conflict between it and the UCCJA . . . .â€Â 
Widdicombe v. Tucker-Cales, 366 S.C. 75, 86, 620 S.E.2d 333, 339 (Ct. App. 2005) (cert. pending) (internal citations omitted).Â  The PKPA mandates three criteria for a court to retain continuing jurisdiction: Â â€œ1) that the original custody determination was entered consistently with the provisions of the PKPA; 2) that the court maintain jurisdiction under its own state law . . . ; and 3) that the state remains the residence of the child or of any contestant.â€Â  Id.; see also 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(d).
Because Florida issued the initial custody decree, we apply the PKPA test to determine if it retained continuing jurisdiction over the matter.Â  At the time of the original custody decree, Mother, Father, and the child were all residents of Florida, where the original decree was issued.Â  Accordingly, Florida met the first requirement for retaining jurisdiction because the original decree was consistent with the provisions of the PKPA. Â See 
Widdicombe at 86-87, 620 S.E.2d at 339.Â  
The second requirement is that Florida maintained jurisdiction under its own state law.Â  Florida has enacted the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, which is the successor to the UCCJA.Â  The relevant section provides:

  1) Â Except as otherwise provided in s. 61.517, a court of this state which has made a child custody determination consistent with s. 61.514 or s. 61.516 has exclusive, continuing jurisdiction over the determination until:
(a) Â A court of this state determines that the child, the childâ€™s parents, and any person acting as a parent do not have a significant connection with this state and that substantial evidence is no longer available in this state concerning the childâ€™s care, protection, training, and personal relationships; or
(b) Â A court of this state or a court of another state determines that the child, the childâ€™s parent, and any person acting as a parent do not presently reside in this state.

Fla. Stat. Â§ 61.515 (2002).Â  Clearly, 1(a) does not apply to the current situation because no Florida court has found that the state lacks a significant connection with the parties.Â  To the contrary, the Florida circuit court repeatedly stated that it has exclusive jurisdiction.Â  As to 1(b), Mother continues to reside in Florida.Â  Accordingly, under Florida law, Florida has met the second requirement to establish exclusive, continuing jurisdiction.
The third criterion, that the state remains the residence of the child or of any contestant, is easily met by Florida as well.Â  Even though the child and Father have moved out of state, Mother has remained a resident of Florida throughout the proceedings.Â  Therefore, Florida meets the third requirement of the PKPA for continuing jurisdiction.
Florida meets all three requirements mandated by the PKPA for it to have continuing jurisdiction.Â  Accordingly, under 28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(d), the South Carolina family court did not have jurisdiction over the matter.
Additionally, the PKPA addresses the specific instance when one stateâ€™s court may modify a custody order issued by another state:

A court of a State may modify a determination of the custody of the same child made by a court of another State, ifâ€”(1) it has jurisdiction to make such a child custody determination; and (2) the court of the other State no longer has jurisdiction, or it has declined to exercise such jurisdiction to modify such determination.

28 U.S.C. Â§ 1738A(f)(2000).Â  This section is nearly identical to the pertinent section in South Carolinaâ€™s version of the UCCJA, which provides:

If a court of another state has made a custody decree, a court of this State shall not modify that decree unless (1) it appears to the court of this State that the court which rendered the decree does not now have jurisdiction under jurisdictional prerequisites substantially in accordance with this subarticle or has declined to assume jurisdiction to modify the decree and (2) the court of this State has jurisdiction.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-810(a) (1976).Â  As discussed above, Florida retains jurisdiction and, therefore, South Carolina was not in a position to modify the Florida courtâ€™s order relating to the childâ€™s custody.
One of the main purposes of legislation like the UCCJA is to avoid conflicting custody decrees between states.Â 
Widdicombe at 87, 620 S.E.2d at 339; see also  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-784(a)(6)(7) 1976) (other purposes include â€œavoid[ing] relitigation of custody decisions of other states in this State insofar as feasibleâ€ and â€œfacilitat[ing] the enforcement of custody decrees of other statesâ€).
In considering similar cases, our courts have given great deference to the jurisdiction of the state that originally ruled on a custody matter.Â 
Widdicombe at 87, 620 S.E.2d at 339-40.Â  â€œCourts which render a custody decree normally retain continuing jurisdiction
to modify the decree under local law.â€Â  Knoth v. Knoth, 297 S.C. 460, 463, 377 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1989). Â â€œAlthough more than one state may meet these jurisdictional requirements, once a custody decree has been entered, the continuing jurisdiction of the decree state is exclusive.â€Â  Sinclair v. Albrecht, 287 S.C. 20, 23, 336 S.E.2d 485, 487 (Ct. App. 1985). Â A childâ€™s residence in another state is not dispositive of this jurisdictional question.Â  Knoth at 464, 377 S.E.2d at 342-43.Â  If the prior state still has sufficient contact with the case to satisfy the jurisdictional requirements, all petitions for modification must be addressed in that state.Â  Id. at 463, 377 S.E.2d at 342.Â  The courtâ€™s previous consideration of the case is one factor in favor of its continued jurisdiction.Â  Id.Â  When a state attempts to exercise continuing jurisdiction over a custody decree on which it has previously ruled, we interpret the jurisdictional requirements in the UCCJA broadly.Â 
Widdicombe at 87, 620 S.E.2d at 340.Â  Because Florida issued the initial custody and properly continued to exercise jurisdiction in the case, South Carolinaâ€™s assumption of jurisdiction was inappropriate under the UCCJA as well.
The Florida courts have continued to exert continuing jurisdiction throughout the proceedings.Â  Under both the PKPA and the UCCJA, the South Carolina family court improperly assumed jurisdiction.Â  Accordingly, because the South Carolina family court lacked jurisdiction, its order is
VACATED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Because we find the family court did not have jurisdiction over this matter, addressing Motherâ€™s additional argument questioning Fatherâ€™s notice of the Florida circuit court proceedings would be improper.

title: Temple v. Tec-Fab
description: In this appeal, the court analyzes, inter alia,  the trebling of damages under South Carolina Code section 41-10-80(C) of the Payment of Wages Act.
text:
Temple v. Tec-Fab, 14195


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Richard Temple, Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Tec-Fab, Inc., and Andrew Lytle, Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. Â 4139
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 24, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
J. Cameron Halford, of Fort Mill, for Appellants-Respondents.
William Thomas Moody, of York, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Andrew Lytle and Tec-Fab, Inc., appeal a circuit court order awarding treble damages to Richard Temple for the withholding of wages in violation of the Payment of Wages Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 41-10-10 to -110 (1986 & Supp. 2005).Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
In December 2000, Lytle sold Temple a fifteen percent interest in his business, Tec-Fab, Inc., for $15,000.Â  Lytle also hired Temple to â€œrun the shop and . . . bring in some business.â€Â  They agreed Tec-Fab would pay Temple $5,000 a month for his services. Â Seven months later, Templeâ€™s salary increased to $6,000 a month.Â  In September 2002, Tec-Fab ceased paying Temple his agreed upon monthly salary. [2]   
In February 2003, Lytle terminated Temple because Tec-Fab lost money and accumulated debt during his employment.Â  At that time, Lytle informed Temple he would receive back pay when Tec-Fab received its accounts from Accutron Technologies, Inc. (Accutron), a customer of Tec-Fab.Â  Shortly thereafter, Accutron issued two checks, which were made jointly payable to Tec-Fab and Temple, for $7,000 and $8,390 respectively.Â  Temple initially accepted personal delivery of these checks because he believed they reduced the amount in wages Tec-Fab owed him.Â  He returned the checks to Accutron, however, after his attorney advised him to do so based on the continuing dispute between Temple and Lytle.Â  Temple then told Accutron to reissue the checks to Tec-Fab only.
Temple sued Lytle and Tec-Fab for withholding his wages in violation of the Payment of Wages Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 41-10-10 to -110 (Supp. 2005).Â  Lytle and Tec-Fab (collectively â€œTec-Fabâ€) answered and counterclaimed.Â  Tec-Fab claimed Temple committed conversion when he failed to remit the Accutron checks to Tec-Fab.Â  They also claimed Temple kept a Ford truck that belonged to Tec-Fab and $5,114.25 that Atlantic Scrap and Processing, L.L.C. (Atlantic Scrap), another customer of Tec-Fab, owed the company.Â Â  
During discovery, Temple had trouble obtaining documents controlled by Tec-Fab.Â  Temple eventually moved the circuit court to compel Tec-Fab to produce the requested documents, which the court granted.Â  Although Tec-Fab produced some of the evidence in question, they waited until two days before trial to produce the bulk of the requested documents.Â  Temple filed a motion in limine alleging an abuse of discovery and seeking sanctions against Tec-Fab.Â  The circuit court granted Templeâ€™s motion and excluded these documents from consideration at trial.Â  
After the trial, the circuit court awarded Temple back pay.Â  The court concluded Respondents could not set-off the amount of the Accutron checks or the Ford truck against the amount in wages Tec-Fab owed Temple, because Temple did not keep the Accutron checks and Respondents permitted Temple to keep the Ford truck.Â  However, the court decided Respondents could set-off the $5,114.25 Temple received from Atlantic Scrap against the amount in wages Tec-Fab owed Temple, because Temple should have remitted the $5,114.25 to Respondents.Â  In computing Templeâ€™s final damages, the trial court subtracted the amount Temple received from Atlantic Scrap and then trebled the remainder.Â  
Tec-Fab moved the circuit court for judgment notwithstanding the verdict and a new trial.Â  The court issued an amended order (1) reopening the trial to determine how much Temple kept from Atlantic Scrap, unless Temple consented to the $5,114.25 granted by the initial order; (2) holding the amount Tec-Fab owed Temple should be based on Templeâ€™s gross wages of $27,500 rather than his net wages of $18,117.50; (3) interpreting section 41-10-80(C) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) to require an award of treble damages; and (4) awarding Temple attorneyâ€™s fees and costs of $7,069.50.Â  Tec-Fab appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order awarding Temple treble damages under section 41-10-80(C), arguing the section does not require the trial court to treble damages.Â  Temple also appeals the order, arguing the circuit court erred in trebling damages after offsetting the damages for money owed instead of trebling damages before the offset.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
Statutory interpretation is a question of law.Â  S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 470, 602 S.E.2d 81, 82 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, the appellate courtâ€™s standard of review extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Okatie River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep,
L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In such cases, the trial courtâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed unless they are wholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an erroneous conception of law.Â  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).
DISCUSSION
I. The Trebling of Damages
Tec-Fab argues the trial court erred in interpreting section 41-10-80(C) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) to require the trial court to treble damages when an employer violates the Payment of Wages Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 14-10-10 to -110 (1986 & Supp. 2005).Â  We agree.Â Â  
The Payment of Wages Act (â€œThe Actâ€) is remedial legislation designed to protect working people and assist them in collecting compensation wrongfully withheld.Â  Abraham v. Palmetto Unified Sch. Dist. No. 1, 343 S.C. 36, 50, 538 S.E.2d 656, 664 (Ct. App. 2000); Dumas v. Infosafe Corp., 320 S.C. 188, 194, 463 S.E.2d 641, 645 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Section 41-10-40(C) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides: â€œ[a]n employer shall not withhold or divert any portion of an employeeâ€™s wages unless the employer is required or permitted to do so by state or federal law . . . .â€Â  The Act requires that â€œ[w]hen an employer separates an employee from the payroll for any reason, the employer shall pay all wages due to the employee within forty-eight hours of the time of separation or the next regular payday which may not exceed thirty days.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-50 (Supp. 2005).Â  The Act further provides:

In case of any failure to pay wages due to an employee as required by Section 41-10-40 or 41-10-50 the employee may recover in a civil action an amount equal to three times the full amount of the unpaid wages, plus costs and reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees as the court may allow. Â 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-80(C) (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).Â  
In Rice v. Multimedia, Inc., 318 S.C. 95, 99, 456 S.E.2d 381, 384 (1995), our supreme court interpreted section 41-10-80(C).Â  The supreme court held that â€œby using â€˜may,â€™ rather than â€˜shall,â€™ the legislature has provided that the penalty is discretionary with the judge.â€Â  Id. at 98, 456 S.E.2d at 383.Â  The supreme court reasoned the legislature intended to give the trial court discretion to award treble damages because the â€œimposition of treble damages in those cases where there is a bona fide dispute would be unjust and harsh.â€Â  Id.
In the present case, the trial court believed section 41-10-80(C) required it to treble damages.Â  This is an error of law. The trial court may award treble damages in such cases, but nothing in section 41-10-80(C) mandates such.Â  Rice, 318 S.C. at 99, 456 S.E.2d at 384.Â  Furthermore, after a thorough review of the record on appeal, we conclude there was a bona fide dispute over the wages in question.Â  The trial court found Temple withheld over $5,000 in proceeds from company scrap sales to which he was not entitled.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court erred in trebling Templeâ€™s damages and modify Templeâ€™s award to $22,385.75 (Templeâ€™s gross unpaid wages less the $5,114.25 withheld in company proceeds).[3]Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to treble Templeâ€™s damages is hereby reversed.
II. Fiduciary Duty and Agency Relationship
Tec-Fab contends the trial court erred in not finding that an agency relationship continued to exist post-termination wherein Temple had a greater fiduciary duty to deposit the Accutron checks with Tec-Fab rather than returning them to Accutron.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review as Tec-Fab did not raise it in its counterclaims or in its motion for a new trial.Â  See Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 40-41, 619 S.E.2d 437, 448-49 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding that when a trial court makes a general ruling on an issue, but does not address the specific argument raised by a party, that party must make a motion asking the trial court to rule on the issue in order to preserve it for appeal.).
III. Piercing the Corporate Veil
Tec-Fab contends the trial court erred in its â€œde facto piercingâ€ of the corporate veil to find Lytle personally liable to Temple.Â  We disagree.
The Act defines employer as â€œevery person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, receiver, or other officer of a court of this State, the State or any political subdivision thereof, and any agent or officer of the above classes employing any person in this State.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-10 (Supp. 2005).Â  Clearly, as an officer and agent of Tec-Fab with knowledge of the failure to pay Temple, and as the person directly responsible for such non-payment, Lytle falls under the definition of â€œemployerâ€ as contemplated by the statute.Â  The trial court was correct in finding Lytle personally liable for the non-payment of wages.Â  The trial court did not have to reach the issue of piercing the corporate veil to do so.
IV. Motion for a New Trial
Tec-Fab argues that the exclusion of evidence and the sanctions conferred constituted an error of law and should result in a new trial.Â  We disagree.
Pursuant to Rule 37(b)(2)(C), SCRCP, when a party fails to obey an order to provide or permit discovery, the court may â€œmake such orders in regard to the failure as are just,â€ including an order dismissing the action or proceeding, or any part thereof.Â  See In re Anonymous Member of the S.C. Bar, 346 S.C. 177, 194, 552 S.E.2d 10, 18 (2001) (â€œ[j]udges must use their authority to make sure that abusive deposition tactics and other forms of discovery abuse do not succeed in their ultimate goal: achieving success through abuse of the discovery rules rather than by the rule of law.â€).Â  The imposition of sanctions is generally entrusted to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Halverson v. Yawn, 328 S.C. 618, 620-21, 493 S.E.2d 883, 884 (Ct. App. 1997).
In the present case, discovery requests were served and, for months, were not answered.Â  The trial court issued an Order Compelling Production, but Tec-Fab still did not provide the documents in question until the day before trial.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in imposing evidentiary sanctions for Tec-Fabâ€™s discovery violations.
For the reasons stated above, the trial courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
 KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] Â Â We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Temple alleges Tec-Fab did not pay him for September 2002, October 2002, and February 2003, and only partially paid him for December 2002.
[3] Due to our conclusion that the trial court erred in trebling Templeâ€™s damages, we need not address Templeâ€™s alleged error in trebling the damages after, rather than before, offsetting his awarded damages.
