title: Haley v. Brown
description: The plaintiff, The Estate of Joshua M. Haley,  appeals from the circuit court's order granting a directed verdict to the defendant, Gary Curtis Brown, on its wrongful death claim.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The Estate of Joshua M. Haley, by and through its Personal Representative, Cynthia Haley,
Appellant,
v.
Gary Curtis Brown, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4140
Heard June 21, 2006 â€“ Filed July 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gene M. Connell, Jr. and Robert John Johnston, both of Surfside Beach, for Appellant.
G. Michael Smith, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  


GOOLSBY, J.:Â Â  This wrongful death action was brought after a bicycle rider ran into the right-rear side panel of a pickup truck.Â  The trial court directed a verdict in favor of the defendant, Gary Curtis Brown, who was the driver of the truck.Â  The plaintiff, the Estate of Joshua M. Haley, by and through its personal representative Cynthia Haley, appeals.Â  The dispositive issue is whether the trial court properly found that, when viewing, as we are required to do,[1] the evidence in the light most favorable to the Estate, the only reasonable conclusion is that the negligence of the bicycle rider, Joshua Haley, outweighed any possible negligence by Brown in light of the sudden emergency in which Brown found himself.Â  We affirm.
Around 6:00 p.m. on August 27, 2001, Joshua, an eight-year-old boy, engaged in play with his brother, Jimmy, and Kyle Sams, both around the same age as Joshua.Â  They were in the parking lot of a vacant bank building in Myrtle Beach located at the corner of Fifth Avenue South and Highway 17.Â  The boys were jumping their bikes over a speed bump located a few feet from the edge of the street at Fifth Avenue South and landing their bikes in or near the street.Â  
A driveway shielded with â€œextremely tallâ€ shrubbery provided access from the parking lot to the street.Â  Brown was driving down Fifth Avenue South when James and Kyle, riding their bicycles, exited the driveway from behind the bushes and entered Fifth Avenue South.Â  Brown immediately swerved his pickup truck to the left to avoid hitting them.Â  Brown turned back to the right to return to his proper lane, but he swerved to the left again when he saw Joshua suddenly appear from the driveway as Joshua jumped over the speed bump.Â  Despite Brownâ€™s efforts, Joshua slammed his bicycle into the side of Brownâ€™s truck just above the tire.Â  The impact threw Joshua into the street.Â  He died the next day.Â  At the time Joshua struck Brownâ€™s vehicle, Joshua was going an estimated 10 to 15 miles per hour.Â  Brown was traveling at or about 25 miles per hour, the posted speed limit.Â  Also, at or near the time of impact, there was a sound of screeching tires; there is no evidence of any other vehicles besides Brownâ€™s in the vicinity.Â  Approximately two to five seconds elapsed from the time Brown avoided the first two boys and Joshua rode his bicycle into the side of Brownâ€™s pickup truck.Â  Â Â 
The only lay witness present at the time of the collision who testified at trial was Kyle, one of the first two riders to dart out as Brown drove down the street.Â  According to Kyleâ€™s uncontradicted testimony, Kyle had just jumped over the speed bump, landed in the street, and gotten onto the sidewalk when he heard screeching tires and then a crash.Â  Kyle turned around to see Joshua, who had been following right behind him, lying in the street.Â  According to Kyle, the accident â€œhappened real quick.â€Â  Kyle acknowledged he was well aware of the need to look both ways before entering a street and agreed the boys had â€œmade a mistake.â€[2]Â  
At trial, an expert witness for the Estate opined as follows: Brown would have traveled between 70 to 90 feet toward the boys once they exited the driveway and entered his field of vision; Brown had between 0.25 seconds and 2.0 seconds, the average human reaction time, to perceive the peril created by the first two children entering the street, make a decision about what evasive action he should take, and execute the evasive maneuver; at a hypothetical speed of 30 miles per hour, Brown would have traveled 44 feet per second, thus traversing his visibility field in approximately 2.0 seconds; from the time Joshuaâ€™s bicycle would have became visible and impacted Brownâ€™s truck, 2.0 seconds would have elapsed, assuming Joshua was traveling 10 miles per hour; and Brown had approximately 2.0 seconds of reaction time to avoid colliding with Joshua.Â  Â Â 
Brown moved for a directed verdict on the issue of liability.Â  The trial court granted Brownâ€™s motion, but apparently inadvertently referred to it as summary judgment.Â  The court stated â€œthere is no reasonable evidence to suggest to the jury that any negligence on the part of the Plaintiff could possibly be exceeded by the -- any perceived negligence on the part of the Defendant . . . .â€Â  
In our view, the trial court properly directed a verdict in this case.Â  The only reasonable inference that can be drawn from the evidence is that Joshuaâ€™s negligence in running into the side of Brownâ€™s truck outweighed any possible negligence by Brown and was the more determinative factor in causing the collision. [3]

In determining whether or not the operator of an automobile was justified in turning out to the left, the usual rules applicable to acts in emergencies generally apply. When the driver of an automobile is confronted with a sudden peril brought about by the negligence of another, he is not held to the exercise of the same degree of care as when he has time for reflection.Â  If he has used due care to avoid meeting such an emergency, and after it arises he exercises such care as a reasonably prudent driver would use under the attendant circumstances, he is not negligent.Â  In Porter v. Cook, 196 S.C. 433, 13 S.E.2d 486, 488 [(1941)], the Court said: â€œIt is settled by a great body of decisions that an automobile driver, who, by the negligence of another and not by his own negligence, is suddenly placed in an emergency and compelled to act instantly to avoid a collision or an injury, is not guilty of negligence
if he makes such a choice as a person of ordinary prudence placed in such a position might make, even though he did not make the wisest choice.â€

Elrod, 243 S.C. at 437-38, 134 S.E.2d at 417.Â  The Elrod court further determined: â€œOrdinarily, the question of sudden emergency is for the jury, but if the proof shows no actionable negligence on the part of the appellant, it is the duty of the Court to so declare as a matter of law.â€Â  Id.; see also Green v. Sparks, 232 S.C. 414, 102 S.E.2d 435 (1958) (noting it was for the jury to determine whether in the sudden emergency which confronted the plaintiff, he exercised ordinary care and judgment in his actions); Alston v. Blue Ridge Transfer Co., 308 S.C. 292, 297, 417 S.E.2d 631, 634 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œThe question of whether a sudden emergency existed is normally a question for the jury, but becomes a question for the court where the facts show no actionable negligence on the part of the defendant.â€).
In Poulos v. James, 254 S.C. 156, 174 S.E.2d 152 (1970), the supreme court noted: â€œAn emergency has been defined as a sudden or unexpected event or combination of circumstances which calls for immediate action.â€Â  Id. at 159, 174 S.E.2d at 154 (quotations omitted).
When the driver of an automobile is confronted with a sudden emergency brought about by the negligence of another and not by his own negligence, and is compelled to act instantly to avoid a collision or an injury, that driver is not guilty of negligence if he makes such a choice as a person of ordinary prudence placed in a like position might make, even though he did not make the wisest choice.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 529 S.E.2d 528 (2000); McVey v. Whittington, 248 S.C. 447, 151 S.E.2d 92 (1966); Benchoff v. Morgan, 302 S.C. 116, 394 S.E.2d 19 (Ct. App. 1990); see also Still v. Blake, 255 S.C. 95, 177 S.E.2d 469 (1970) (concluding sudden emergency doctrine properly was charged to jury where plaintiff veered left to avoid colliding with defendantâ€™s vehicle, which had signaled to turn right but unexpectedly turned left); Alston, 308 S.C. at 297, 417 S.E.2d at 634 (emphasizing that, where a motorist is suddenly placed in an emergency situation, through no fault of his own, and is compelled to act instantly to avoid a collision, he is not negligent if he makes a choice that a person of ordinary judgment might make if placed in the same emergency situation); accord Spahn v. Town of Port Royal, 326 S.C. 632, 486 S.E.2d 507 (Ct. App. 1997) (finding sudden emergency doctrine properly was charged to jury where police officerâ€™s vehicle injured plaintiff as plaintiff was trying to retrieve his boat from middle of road), affâ€™d as modified, 330 S.C. 168, 499 S.E.2d 205 (1998); Singletary v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Educ., 316 S.C. 153, 447 S.E.2d 231 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating it was a jury question on whether defendant school bus driver acted prudently under sudden emergency doctrine when driver failed to pull off foggy highway after bus stalled, and was struck from rear by plaintiffâ€™s vehicle).Â  In order for the doctrine of sudden emergency to apply, it must be shown that: (1) the person was confronted with an emergency, or with what appeared to be an emergency; (2) the emergency was not caused or contributed to by the person; and (3) in meeting the emergency, the person acted as a person of reasonable prudence would or might have acted under the same or similar circumstances.
The sudden emergency doctrine is intended to protect a driver who, while acting with due care, suddenly finds himself in an emergency situation due to the negligent or wrongful acts of another.Â  Clark, 339 S.C. at 392, 529 S.E.2d at 540. Â The doctrine does not apply when a partyâ€™s own negligence creates the very emergency in which he finds himself.Â  Id.
Persons who have to act in the face of sudden emergency are not to be judged in the light of later events but are to be judged under all the circumstances which surround them at the time by the standard of what a person of ordinary prudence would have been likely to do under the same conditions.Â  Watson v. Aiken, 243 S.C. 368, 133 S.E.2d 833 (1963); Porter v. Cook, 196 S.C. 433, 13 S.E.2d 486 (1941).
Sudden emergency is not a defense in and of itself.Â  Brooks v. Brooks, 288 S.C. 71, 339 S.E.2d 531 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  It is simply a part of the overall law of negligence and is charged to the jury in a proper case to assist the jury in applying the principles of negligence.Â  Wiggins v. Thomas, 264 S.C. 360, 215 S.E.2d 426 (1975); Brooks, 288 S.C. at 73, 339 S.E.2d at 532.
With the adoption of comparative negligence, the sudden emergency doctrine is now only a factor in the total fault analysis.Â  The Supreme Court of Kentucky, in Regenstreif v. Phelps, 142 S.W.3d 1 (Ky. 2004), analyzed whether the sudden emergency doctrine had been subsumed by comparative negligence:

The sudden emergency qualification was not subsumed by the comparative negligence doctrine.Â  In comparative negligence, the plaintiffâ€™s damages are reduced in proportion to his or her fault.Â  A partyâ€™s fault is determined by evaluating his or her conduct in consideration of the duties he or she is bound to observe.Â  â€œ[T]he sudden emergency doctrine is merely an expression of the reasonably prudent person standard of care. It expresses the notion that the law requires no more from an actor than is reasonable to expect in the event of an emergency.â€  In other words, in the comparative negligence case, â€œ[t]he sudden emergency instruction informs the jury . . . how it is to allocate fault and apportion damages when the conduct of the person in question is that of an â€˜ordinarily prudent personâ€™ when faced with an emergency situation.â€Â 
â€œSignificantly, the doctrine explains to the jury the standard of conduct expected of defendants and plaintiffs who act under the stress of an emergency situation.â€
With the adoption of comparative negligence, the sudden emergency doctrine is now only a factor in the total fault analysis. . . .
The core principle of comparative negligence is that â€œ[o]ne is liable for an amount equal to his degree of fault, no more and no less.â€
The sudden emergency doctrine necessarily complements this principle in those particular cases where additional circumstances alter the way in which oneâ€™s degree of fault should be determined. We find no friction between comparative negligence and the sudden emergency doctrine . . . .

Regenstreif, 142 S.W.3d at 5-6 (footnotes omitted).Â  Unlike the Regenstreif court, the Court of Appeals of Tennessee, in Ross v. Vanderbilt Univ. Med. Ctr., 27 S.W.3d 523 (Tenn. Ct. App. 2000), found the sudden emergency doctrine was subsumed into Tennesseeâ€™s comparative fault scheme.Â  The Ross court inculcated:

The main issue in this case is brought about by the ongoing effort of our courts to resolve certain pre-McIntyre doctrines in accord with a system of comparative fault.Â  Specifically at issue is the sudden emergency doctrine which has been addressed by the supreme court on two occasions since the adoption of comparative fault.Â  First, in Eaton v. McClain, 891 S.W.2d 587 (Tenn. 1994), the court took the opportunity to provide trial courts with some guidance as to how to apportion fault between parties.Â  In so doing, the court stated, as dicta, that â€œ[t]he policy considerations underlying . . . the doctrine of contributory negligence . . . have been implicitly subsumed by our decision in McIntyre and should also impact the juryâ€™s apportionment of fault between the parties in an appropriate case.â€Â  Id. at 592.Â  The court proceeded to say that â€œ[i]n summary, the percentage of fault assigned to each party should be
dependent upon all the circumstances of the case, including such factors as: . . . the existence of a sudden emergency requiring a hasty decision.â€Â  Id. Again, in McCall v. Wilder, 913 S.W.2d 150 (Tenn. 1995), the sudden emergency doctrine was addressed and was, this time, actually at issue in a case involving an automobile accident.Â  The defendant, the administrator of the decedentâ€™s estate, alleged that the accident was an unavoidable consequence of a sudden emergency created when the decedent suffered a seizure while driving.Â  The court of appeals had upheld the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment reasoning â€œthat the case fell within the â€˜established principles in this state that an automobile accident resulting from an unavoidable sudden emergency, such as an epileptic seizure, negates negligence.â€™â€Â  Id. at 152.Â  The supreme court vacated the award of summary judgment holding that â€œ[t]he doctrine no longer constitutes a defense as a matter of law but, if at issue, must be considered as a factor in the total comparative fault analysis. Accordingly, the doctrine of sudden emergency does not negate defendantâ€™s liability in the case before us as a matter of law.â€Â  Id. at 157.Â  In so holding, the court quoted Eaton stating that â€œ[t]he sudden emergency doctrine . . . has now been subsumed into Tennesseeâ€™s comparative fault scheme.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).
. . . .
As articulated in Eaton and McCall, the adoption of a comparative fault scheme modifies the way that the sudden emergency doctrine operates as applied to both plaintiffs and defendants seeking to rely on the doctrine.Â  Specifically with regard to plaintiffs, the doctrine is no longer needed as an exception to contributory negligence to ameliorate the plaintiffâ€™s claim.Â  Rather, the circumstances taken into account by this doctrine are now some of many considerations to be addressed when assessing relative degrees of fault.Â  Eaton, 891 S.W.2d at 592.

 As for defendants, prior to McIntyre, the sudden emergency doctrine constituted a defense as a matter of law if properly established by the defendant.Â  McCall, 913 S.W.2d at 157 (â€œ[t]he doctrine no longer constitutes a defense as a matter of lawâ€). Now, it is only a factor in the total fault analysis.Â  Id.Â  This is true in a comparative fault analysis when both parties are allegedly at fault. It is likewise true when the analysis is only of the defendantâ€™s fault because, as in the case at bar, there has been no allegation that the plaintiff was at fault.

Ross, 27 S.W.3d at 527-28; see also Eaton v. McLain, 891 S.W.2d 587 (Tenn. 1994) (stating the sudden emergency doctrine has been implicitly subsumed and should impact the juryâ€™s apportionment of fault between the parties in an appropriate case).Â  Similarly, the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, in Jefferson v. Soileau, 864 So. 2d 250 (La. Ct. App. 2003), explicated:

The City-Parish also claims that the â€œsudden emergencyâ€ instruction was inappropriate under the facts of this case because the â€œsudden emergencyâ€ doctrine was subsumed in comparative fault.Â  However, the First Circuit recently stated in Duzon v. Stallworth, 01-1187 (La. App. 1 Cir. 12/11/02), 866 So. 2d 837, writs denied, 03-0589, 03-0605 (La. 5/2/03), 842 So. 2d 1101, 1110, that even though the â€œsudden emergencyâ€ doctrine was developed when contributory negligence was a complete bar to recovery, we continue to apply the doctrine today.

Jefferson , 864 So. 2d at 253.
The analysis and ruling in regard to the doctrine of last clear chance by the Spahn court is instructive and edifying as we examine the viability of the doctrine of sudden emergency as juxtaposed to the doctrine of comparative negligence.Â  Concomitantly, I hold that the doctrine of sudden emergency has been subsumed by adoption of comparative negligence such that it remains a factor for the juryâ€™s consideration in comparing the partiesâ€™ fault, but that it does NOT totally relieve a party of his or her negligence.
The circuit judge erred in finding the sudden emergency doctrine precluded this case from being submitted to the jury. 
V.Â  Comparative Negligence
The Supreme Court of South Carolina adopted the doctrine of comparative negligence in Nelson v. Concrete Supply Co., 303 S.C. 243, 399 S.E.2d 783 (1991):

Having determined comparative negligence is the more equitable doctrine, we now join the vast majority of our sister jurisdictions and adopt it as the law of South Carolina to the extent set forth below.Â  For an exhaustive analytical discussion of the history and merits of comparative negligence, we refer the bench and bar to the opinion of Chief Judge Sanders in Langley v. Boyter, 284 S.C. 162, 325 S.E.2d 550 (Ct. App. 1984).
For all causes of action arising on or after July 1, 1991, a plaintiff in a negligence action may recover damages if his or her negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.Â  The amount of the plaintiffâ€™s recovery shall be reduced in proportion to the amount of his or her negligence.Â  If there is more than one defendant, the plaintiffâ€™s negligence shall be compared to the combined negligence of all defendants.Â  See Elder v. Orluck, 511 Pa. 402, 515 A.2d 517 (1986).

Nelson, 303 S.C. at 244-45, 399 S.E.2d at 784 (footnote omitted).Â  This Court further discussed the doctrine in Ott v. Pittman, 320 S.C. 72, 463 S.E.2d 101 (Ct. App. 1995):

If a plaintiff was negligent as a matter of law, and that negligence proximately caused the injury complained of, under the doctrine of contributory negligence, the plaintiff was automatically barred from recovery.Â  Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, negligence by the plaintiff does not automatically bar recovery by the plaintiff unless his negligence is greater than that of the defendant.

Ott, 320 S.C. at 80, 463 S.E.2d at 106; see also Hopson v. Clary, 321 S.C. 312, 468 S.E.2d 305 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating plaintiffâ€™s claim was barred under comparative negligence doctrine because plaintiffâ€™s own negligence was, as a matter of law, greater than any negligence attributable to defendant and the more determinative factor in causing the accident).Â  Comparative negligence is an affirmative defense in South Carolina.Â  Ross v. Paddy, 340 S.C. 428, 532 S.E.2d 612 (Ct. App. 2000).
Under the comparative negligence doctrine, a plaintiff may only recover damages if his own negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.Â  Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 363 S.C. 421, 611 S.E.2d 488 (2005); Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 529 S.E.2d 710 (2000); Trivelas v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 357 S.C. 545, 593 S.E.2d 504 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Generally, under a less than or equal to comparative negligence rule, determination of respective degrees of negligence attributable to the plaintiff and the defendant presents a question of fact for the jury, at least where conflicting inferences may be drawn.Â  Trivelas, 357 S.C. at 549-50, 593 S.E.2d at 506; Brown v. Smalls, 325 S.C. 547, 481 S.E.2d 444 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Hurd, 363 S.C. at 429, 611 S.E.2d at 492 (noting determination of respective degrees of negligence attributable to plaintiff and defendant presents a question of fact for the jury, at least where conflicting inferences may be drawn); Thomasko v. Poole, 349 S.C. 7, 11, 561 S.E.2d 597, 599 (2002) (â€œBecause the term is relative and dependant on the facts of a particular case, comparing the negligence of two parties is ordinarily a question of fact for the jury.â€); Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife & Marine Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 491 S.E.2d 571 (1997) (holding comparison of plaintiffâ€™s negligence with that of defendant is question of fact for jury to decide).Â  â€œAccordingly, apportionment of negligence, which determines both whether a plaintiff is barred from recovery or can recover some of his damages and the proportion of damages to which he is entitled, is usually a function of the jury.â€Â  Brown, 325 S.C. at 559, 481 S.E.2d at 451.
In a comparative negligence case, the trial court should grant a motion for directed verdict if the sole reasonable inference which may be drawn from the evidence is that the non-moving partyâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.Â  Hurd, 363 S.C. at 429, 611 S.E.2d at 492; Thomasko, 349 S.C. at 11, 561 S.E.2d at 599; Bloom, 339 S.C. at 422, 529 S.E.2d at 713; see also Trivelas, 357 S.C. at 549-50, 593 S.E.2d at 506 (â€œIn a comparative negligence case, the trial court should only determine judgment as a matter of law if the sole reasonable inference which may be drawn from the evidence is that the plaintiffâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.â€).Â  â€œFor these reasons, this Court is reticent to endorse directed verdicts in cases involving comparative negligence.â€Â  Thomasko, 349 S.C. at 11, 561 S.E.2d at 599.
CONCLUSION
I hold the trial judge erred in granting a directed verdict in Brownâ€™s favor.Â  The evidence is susceptible to more than one inference.Â  An analysis of the evidentiary record reveals paradigmatically the existence of factual issues which must be resolved by the trial jury.Â  Accordingly, I VOTE to REVERSE the judgeâ€™s order granting Brownâ€™s directed verdict motion and REMAND the case.

[1]Â  See, e.g., Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 363 S.C. 421, 426, 611 S.E.2d 488, 491 (2005) (â€œWhen reviewing a ruling on a motion for directed verdict, we must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€).
[2]Â  In South Carolina, the conduct of a minor is judged by the standard of behavior to be expected of a child of like age, intelligence, and experience under like circumstances.Â  Standard v. Shine, 278 S.C. 337, 339, 295 S.E.2d 786, 787 (1982).Â  The undisputed evidence was that Joshua and the other children knew of the need to look before entering a street.Â  Kyleâ€™s mother testified her son had known â€œfor some timeâ€ of the need to look both ways before entering a street, he had been trained in this for his own safety, and she had the impression he understood this for several years prior to the accident.Â  Likewise, Joshuaâ€™s mother conceded her sons, including Joshua, â€œknew the rules of the roadâ€ and â€œ[t]hey knew not to go in the road.â€Â Â Â  Â 
[3]Â  Under comparative negligence, the plaintiff in a negligence action may recover damages only when his or her negligence is not greater than that of the defendant.Â  Nelson v. Concrete Supply Co., 303 S.C. 243, 245 & n.1, 399 S.E.2d 783, 784 & n.1 (1991) (finding the plaintiff, who ran into the back of a tractor-trailer, was not entitled to recover damages because there was no negligence on the part of the truck driver as a matter of law).Â  The trial court should grant a motion for a directed verdict in a comparative negligence case when â€œthe only reasonable inference that may be drawn from the evidence is that the plaintiffâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.â€Â  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife & Marine Res. Depâ€™t,  328 S.C. 24, 33, 491 S.E.2d 571, 575 (1997); cf. Lydia v. Horton, 355 S.C. 36, 40, 583 S.E.2d 750, 752-53 (2003) (noting if the evidence supports only one conclusion, the comparative fault of the plaintiff and the defendant becomes a question of law for the trial judge; the court held, in a negligent entrustment action, the plaintiffâ€™s admission that he was intoxicated and lost control of a borrowed vehicle exceeded the ownerâ€™s alleged negligence in loaning him the vehicle as a matter of law).
[4] Â The sudden emergency doctrine does not bar a plaintiffâ€™s claim as a matter of law, but it is relevant in determining whether there is any reasonable inference that the defendantâ€™s alleged negligence outweighed that of the plaintiff.Â  See Wiggins v. Thomas, 264 S.C. 360, 365, 215 S.E.2d 426, 428 (1975) (stating the doctrine of sudden emergency is a part of the overall law of negligence); Watson v. Aiken, 243 S.C. 368, 373, 133 S.E.2d 833, 836 (1963) (observing when a person faces a sudden emergency, he is not to be judged in light of later events, but rather, is to be judged in light of all the surrounding circumstances, by the standard of what a person of ordinary prudence likely would have done under the same conditions); Singletary v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Educ., 316 S.C. 153, 157, 447 S.E.2d 231, 233 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œWhere a motorist is suddenly placed in an emergency situation, through no fault of his own, and is compelled to act instantly to avoid a collision, he is not negligent if he makes a choice that a person of ordinary judgment might make if placed in the same emergency situation.â€); Alston v. Blue Ridge Transfer Co., 308 S.C. 292, 297-98, 417 S.E.2d 631, 634 (Ct. App. 1992) (noting the question of whether a sudden emergency existed, normally a question for the jury, can be a question for the court if the facts show no actionable negligence on the part of the defendant; the court found, as a matter of law, that the defendant made every reasonable effort to avoid a collision by attempting to brake and pull off the road when faced with the plaintiffâ€™s vehicle crossing the center line and that the allegedly excessive speed of the defendant was not the proximate cause of the accident).Â  
[5]Â  The Estateâ€™s expert witness had suggested that Brown was negligent in failing to apply his brakes rather than swerving to his left, but the expert witness agreed a collision would have occurred between the truck and Joshuaâ€™s bicycle â€œeven if [Brown had] hit the brakes.â€ Â Furthermore, the evidence of screeching brakes just before Joshua crashed into Brownâ€™s truck and the lack of evidence of any other vehicles in the vicinity suggests Brown applied his brakes in an emergency fashion at the time of the collision.Â  
[6] Â To the extent the Estate argues the doctrine of last clear chance precludes a directed verdict in this case, we find the doctrine, like sudden emergency, is simply one factor to be considered in determining the overall negligence of the parties.Â  Although we agree comparative negligence normally presents a jury question, where, after consideration of all the relevant factors, the only reasonable inference is that the plaintiffâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent, it becomes a matter of law for the trial court.Â  See Spahn v. Town of Port Royal, 330 S.C. 168, 173, 499 S.E.2d 205, 208 (1998) (stating the doctrine of last clear chance has been subsumed by the adoption of comparative negligence and is simply one factor to be considered in analyzing the partiesâ€™ relative negligence); Rothrock v. Copeland, 305 S.C. 402, 405, 409 S.E.2d 366, 368 (1991) (holding last clear chance is not applicable where an emergency arises so suddenly that the defendant has no reasonable opportunity to avoid it); Bennett v. Wilbro, Inc., 310 S.C. 371, 374 n.1, 426 S.E.2d 812, 813 n.1 (Ct. App. 1992) (noting â€œ[t]he [last clear chance] doctrine allows recovery to a victim who negligently subjects himself to harm only if the defendant could or should have discovered the victimâ€™s peril and thereafter fails to exercise reasonable care to avoid injury to the victimâ€ (emphasis added)).
[7] Â 321 S.C. 312, 468 S.E.2d 305 (Ct. App. 1996).
[8]Â  Id. at 313, 468 S.E.2d 307.

title: Skipper v. SCDC
description: The South Carolina Department of Corrections appeals the circuit court's order finding Skipper was denied both a liberty interest in prison employment and due process with regard to SCDC's drug-testing policy.
text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ronald Deâ€™Ray Skipper, Respondent,
v.
South Carolina Department of Corrections, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4141
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed July 31, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
Christopher L. Murphy and Â James A. Stuckey, Jr., both of Charleston, for Appellant.
Ronald Deâ€™Ray Skipper, of Bishopville, pro se.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  The South Carolina Department of Corrections (SCDC) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding Ronald Deâ€™Ray Skipper was denied both a liberty interest in prison employment and due process with regard to SCDCâ€™s drug-testing policy.Â  SCDC contends there is no liberty interest in prison employment and that Skipper was afforded due process prior to his disciplinary conviction for drug possession.Â  We reverse.[1]Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
FACTS
Skipper, an inmate at Evans Correctional Institution,[2] was employed at the facility through SCDC and the privately run Prison Industries Enterprises.Â  Â Prison Industries is a voluntary program which serves the SCDC by employing and training inmates. Â Inmates choosing to participate in the program receive the prevailing wage of the local area for the particular job they perform with deductions taken for taxes, victim compensation, and room and board. 
On January 18, 2001, Skipper was randomly selected for testing under the SCDC drug-testing policy, and he tested positive for marijuana.Â  On January 31, 2001, Skipper was re-tested and his urine was again positive for marijuana.Â  Immediately following this test, a follow-up test was performed and it confirmed the positive result. 
On February 7, 2001, a disciplinary hearing was held before prison officials, and Skipper was found guilty of possession of marijuana.Â  This disciplinary conviction resulted in Skipper losing fifteen days of canteen privileges.Â  Additionally, as per Prison Industriesâ€™ policy, Skipper was terminated from his job because of this disciplinary conviction. Â On September 21, 2001, Skipper was transferred from Evans Correctional Institution to Lee Correctional Institution, a facility which does not utilize the Prison Industries program.Â  
Skipper appealed his disciplinary conviction through a two-step inmate grievance procedure.Â  His appeal was reviewed and denied by the institutional grievance coordinator and the warden.Â  After exhausting his inmate grievance appeals, Skipper appealed to the Administrative Law Judge Division (ALJD).Â  The ALJ dismissed Skipperâ€™s appeal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction on the ground the SCDC â€œdid not infringe a liberty interest when it punished Skipper with canteen restrictions for violating a prison disciplinary rule.â€Â  
Skipper then appealed to the circuit court, and the court remanded the matter back to the ALJD to consider whether the possible effect of the challenged disciplinary conviction on Skipperâ€™s parole chances implicated a protected liberty interest.Â  The ALJ again dismissed the appeal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction stating â€œthe mere possibility of an effect on parole eligibility is too tenuous to constitute a deprivation of a liberty interest.â€Â  The ALJ further found â€œno liberty interest is implicated when an inmate is faced with lesser penalties such as the loss of television, canteen, or telephone privileges.â€ 
Skipper again appealed to the circuit court, and the court ruled in his favor.Â  The court found as a matter of law that Skipperâ€™s loss of employment implicated a liberty interest, and SCDCâ€™s refusal to send Skipperâ€™s urine for further testing interfered with his right to due process.Â  SCDC appeals.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Mootness
In its brief, SCDC asserts the circuit court erred in finding:Â  (1) SCDCâ€™s refusal to provide Skipper with Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry (GC/MS) confirmation of his drug test result interfered with Skipperâ€™s right to due process in his disciplinary conviction; and (2) Skipper had a liberty interest in prison employment which potentially afforded a basis for a claim under 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.Â  
Although we will address these arguments, we find it necessary as a threshold matter to analyze whether the issue regarding Skipperâ€™s prison employment is moot.
In its May 23, 2003 order, the circuit court, in finding violations of a liberty interest and due process rights, stated only that Skipper was entitled to â€œsome relief.â€Â  SCDC filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment and included a request that, in the alternative, the circuit court clarify what relief should be awarded to Skipper. Â In response, the circuit court issued a Form 4 order denying the motion.Â  The court failed to address the issue of specific relief. Â 
During the course of his appeal, Skipper was transferred to the Lee Correctional Institution, a facility which does not provide the privilege of employment with Prison Industries Enterprises.Â  Given the authority to determine an inmateâ€™s location rests with SCDC, this court may not order his return to Evans Correctional Facility or to another correctional facility which offers Skipperâ€™s desired employment. Â Consequently, as will be discussed, we find any issue regarding potential employment relief for Skipper is moot. 
Generally, this court does not have the authority to dictate to the SCDC where an inmate should be housed. Â In South Carolina, the authority to determine where an inmate is housed is vested in the Department of Corrections.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-30(A) (Supp. 2005) (â€œNotwithstanding any other provision of law, a person convicted of an offense against the State must be in the custody of the Department of Corrections, and the department shall designate the place of confinement where the sentence must be served.â€); see also S.C. Const. art. XII, Â§ 2 (â€œThe General Assembly shall establish institutions for the confinement of all persons convicted of such crimes as may be designated by law, and shall provide for the custody, maintenance, health, welfare, education, and rehabilitation of the inmates.â€).
Absent an atypical and significant hardship on the inmate, or an arbitrary, capricious, or biased decision by the prison, the court has no authority to interfere with inmate housing decisions.Â  See Sandin v. Conner, 515 U.S. 472, 486 (1995)(holding that thirty days of solitary confinement when compared with inmateâ€™s overall prison environment, was not the â€œtype of atypical, significant deprivation in which a State might conceivably create a liberty interestâ€); Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 381, 527 S.E.2d 742, 756 (2000) (finding judicial review of inmate disputes is limited to â€œdetermine whether â€˜the challenged conditions or degree of confinement are within the sentence imposed and are not otherwise violative of the Constitution,â€™ or whether prison officials have acted arbitrarily, capriciously, or from personal biasâ€ (quoting Brown v. Evatt, 322 S.C. 189, 194, 470 S.E.2d 848, 851 (1996))); Crowe v. Leeke, 273 S.C. 763, 764, 259 S.E.2d 614, 615 (1979) (holding transfer within prison system or downgrading of custody status is not subject to judicial review as long as prison officials do not act arbitrarily, capriciously, or from personal bias or prejudice).
Because Skipper has not specifically challenged his transfer to the Lee Correctional Institution and our authority with respect to internal inmate decisions is limited, we are placed in a position of not being able to grant effectual relief.Â  Given we are unable to grant this relief, we find the issue is moot. See Collins Music Co. v. IGT, 365 S.C. 544, 549, 619 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ct. App. 2005)(noting a matter becomes moot when some event occurs making it impossible to grant effectual relief). 
II.Â  Liberty Interest in Prison Employment and Due Process
SCDC argues the circuit court erred in finding that Skipper had a liberty interest in prison employment which potentially afforded him a basis for a claim under 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.Â  We agree.
Even though this court is without authority to grant Skipper relief in terms of ordering a transfer to a facility offering the Prison Industries program, we address the merits of this issue in the interest of thoroughness given Skipperâ€™s liberty interest argument may be broadly construed as also including a challenge to his transfer to a facility that does not offer the employment program.
â€œ[A]dministrative matters entitled to review by the ALJD â€˜typically arise in two ways:Â  (1) when an inmate is disciplined and punishment is imposed and (2) when an inmate believes prison officials have erroneously calculated his sentence, sentence-related credits, or custody status.â€™â€Â  Sullivan v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 355 S.C. 437, 441, 586 S.E.2d 124, 126 (2003) (quoting Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 369, 527 S.E.2d 742, 750 (2000)).Â  We also recognize that a condition of confinement could implicate a state-created liberty interest, thus requiring minimal due process.Â  See Sullivan, 355 S.C. at 442, 586 S.E.2d at 126 (â€œ[S]tates may create liberty interests which are protected by the Due Process Clause, but . . .Â  â€˜these interests will be generally limited to freedom from restraint which . . . imposes atypical and significant hardship on the inmate in relation to the ordinary incidents of prison life.â€™â€ (quoting Sandin v. Conner, 515 U.S. 472, 484 (1995))). 
â€œCourts traditionally have adopted a â€˜hands offâ€™ doctrine regarding judicial involvement in prison disciplinary procedures and other internal prison matters, although they must intercede when infringements complained of by an inmate reach constitutional dimensions.â€Â  Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 382, 527 S.E.2d at 757. In other words, an inmateâ€™s complaint must encompass an infringement of a liberty interest that imposes an atypical and significant hardship on the inmate to trigger due process guarantees and judicial review.
The Prison Industries program, like a work release program, is statutorily created.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-430(A) (Supp. 2005) (â€œThe Director of the Department of Corrections may establish a program involving the use of inmate labor . . . in private industry for the manufacturing and processing of goods, wares, or merchandise or the provision of services or another business or commercial enterprise considered by the director to enhance the general welfare of South Carolina.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-20 (Supp. 2005) (outlining guidelines for inmates recommended for work release).Â  Both have the general purpose of providing inmate employment during incarceration as a means of rehabilitation.Â  Because the work release program is similar to the Prison Industries program, we find instructive precedent analyzing the work release program.Â  
Our supreme court has decided that â€œ[t]he Board of Corrections has discretion whether to allow an inmate even to participate in a work release program.â€Â  Gunter v. State, 298 S.C. 113, 116, 378 S.E.2d 443, 444 (1989), overruled in part on other grounds by Griffin v. State, 315 S.C. 285, 433 S.E.2d 862 (1993). â€œParticipation in a work-release program is a privilege, not a right. Â Thus, the denial of participation in a work-release program, standing alone, affords no basis for a claim under 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.â€Â  Quillian v. Evatt, 315 S.C. 489, 491, 445 S.E.2d 639, 640 (Ct. App. 1994) (citation omitted). 
In an analogous situation, the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has stated:Â Â Â Â Â  

It is well settled that federal courts do not occupy â€œthe role of super wardens of state penal institutions,â€ and â€œdo not sit to supervise state prisons.â€Â  In
particular, the classifications and work assignments of prisoners in such institutions are matters of prison administration, within the discretion of the prison administrators, and do not require fact-finding hearings as a prerequisite for the exercise of such discretion.Â  To hold that they are â€œwithin reach of the procedural protections of the Due Process Clause would place the Clause astride the day-to-day functioning of state prisons and involve the judiciary in issues and discretionary decisions that are not the business of federal judges.â€Â  

Altizer v. Paderick, 569 F.2d 812, 812-13 (4th Cir. 1978) (citations omitted).
More recently, the United States Supreme Court took the opportunity to clarify the law with respect to state-created liberty interests in prison systems that are protected by the Due Process Clause.Â  Sandin v. Conner, 515 U.S. 472 (1995).Â  The Court noted that â€œthese interests will be generally limited to freedom from restraint which, while not exceeding the sentence in such an unexpected manner as to give rise to protection by the Due Process Clause of its own force, nonetheless imposes atypical and significant hardship on the inmate in relation to the ordinary incidents of prison life.â€Â  Id. at 484 (citations omitted).Â  In ruling on Connerâ€™s case, the Court established directives for future cases.Â  Specifically, the Court held that â€œConnerâ€™s discipline in segregated confinement did not present the type of atypical, significant deprivation in which a State might conceivably create a liberty interest.â€Â  Id. at 486.
Applying the above-outlined principles, we find Skipperâ€™s participation in the Prison Industries program is not a right, but a privilege. Â Not all prisons provide this opportunity to their inmates, and those that do provide this option are inundated with inmate requests and forced to maintain long waiting lists.Â  This employment program does not meet the test for a state-created liberty interest as outlined in Sandin because it does not present an atypical, significant hardship on inmates who are not permitted to participate.Â  Consequently, Skipper, in being terminated from his prison employment, did not suffer an infringement upon his liberty interests.3Â  Moreover, it is not a requirement of the due process and equal protection clauses of either the State or the United States Constitutions that if the State undertakes to provide rehabilitative facilities, it must provide such facilities to all prisoners or to none.Â  See McLamore v. State, 257 S.C. 413, 424, 186 S.E.2d 250, 256 (1972) (finding that inmate was not denied constitutional rights under the Due Process or Equal Protection clauses of the State and United States Constitutions where certain educational and rehabilitative services available to some inmates at the SCDC were not available to him).4
We are cognizant that our holding on this issue may initially appear to be in conflict with our supreme courtâ€™s decision in Wicker v. South Carolina Department of Corrections, 360 S.C. 421, 602 S.E.2d 56 (2004).Â  We believe, however, that the two cases are distinguishable.Â  Like Skipper, Wicker participated in the Prison Industries Program at the Evans Correctional Institute.Â  During the first 320 hours of his employment, Wicker was paid $.25-.75 per hour.Â  After completing his training, Wicker was paid an hourly wage of $5.25 per hour.Â  Due to this wage disparity, Wicker filed an inmate grievance in which he asserted his training wages violated the Prevailing Wage Statute outlined in section 24-3-430(D).Â  This section specifically provides that â€œ[n]o inmate participating in the program may earn less than the prevailing wage for work of similar nature in the private sector.â€Â  Id. at 423, 602 S.E.2d at 57.Â  After the Department of Corrections (DOC) denied Wickerâ€™s grievance, Wicker appealed to the ALJ.Â  The ALJ ruled in favor of Wicker, finding there was no statutory authority for the DOC to pay less than the prevailing wage.Â  Id.Â  The circuit court affirmed the ALJ.Â  On appeal, the DOC contended Wicker was not entitled to relief under the applicable statute.Â  The supreme court affirmed the decision of the circuit court.Â  In so holding, the court found that â€œthe stateâ€™s statutory mandate that inmates be paid the prevailing wageâ€ created a liberty interest which may not be denied without due process.Â  Id. at 424-25, 602 S.E.2d at 58.Â  Accordingly, the court held Wicker could not be denied this right without being afforded due process of law.Â  Id. at 424, 602 S.E.2d at 57.
The instant case is distinguishable from Wicker given there is no statutory requirement that all correctional facilities employ the Prison Industries Program or that an inmate participate.Â  In fact, the statute which creates the program specifically provides the establishment of the program is discretionary and that an inmateâ€™s participation in the program is voluntary.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-430(A) (Supp. 2005) (â€œThe Director of the Department of Corrections may establish a program involving the use of inmate labor . . . in private industry.â€)(emphasis added); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-430(C) (Supp. 2005) (â€œAn inmate may participate in the program established pursuant to this section only on a voluntary basis and only after he has been informed of the conditions of his employment.â€)(emphasis added); see also Kennedy v. South Carolina Ret. Sys., 345 S.C. 339, 352-53, 549 S.E.2d 243, 250 (2001) (â€œThe use of the word â€˜mayâ€™ signifies permission and generally means that the action spoken of is optional or discretionary unless it appears to require that it be given any other meaning in the present statute.â€).Â  Because there is no statutorily-created right for an inmate to participate in the program or remain in the program indefinitely, we find in Skipperâ€™s case, unlike Wickerâ€™s, there does not exist a state-created liberty interest.
III.Â Â Â  Drug Test
SCDC further contends the circuit court erred in finding its refusal to provide Skipper with a Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry (GC/MS) test to confirm the result of his failed drug test interfered with Skipperâ€™s right to due process.Â  We agree.
In establishing the minimal requirements of due process in a prison disciplinary proceeding involving serious misconduct, our supreme court has relied on precedent from the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Wolff v. McDonnell, 418 U.S. 539, 563-72 (1974).Â  In Al-Shabazz, our supreme court outlined the requirements as follows:

(1) that advance written notice of the charge be given to the inmate at least twenty-four hours before the hearing; (2) that factfinders must prepare a written statement of the evidence relied on and reasons for the disciplinary action; (3) that the inmate should be allowed to call witnesses and present documentary evidence, provided there is no undue hazard to institutional safety or correctional goals; (4) that counsel substitute (a fellow inmate or a prison employee) should be allowed to help illiterate inmates or in complex cases an inmate cannot handle alone; and (5) that the persons hearing the matter, who may be prison officials or employees, must be impartial. 

Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 371, 527 S.E.2d at 751 (citing Wolff v. McDonnell, 418 U.S. 539, 563-72 (1974)).
Here, there has been no allegation that these requirements were not satisfied by the SCDC procedure.Â  The argument posed by Skipper and accepted by the circuit court is that SCDCâ€™s failure to send Skipperâ€™s urine samples for further testing deprived him of due process.Â  We fail to see how the due process requirements delineated in Al-Shabazz could be construed in this fashion, and we find that SCDC complied with the procedural due process requirements in this matter. 
Moreover, SCDC developed drug-testing procedures which were followed for Skipperâ€™s testing.Â  Contrary to Skipperâ€™s assertions, it was not the policy of SCDC to send all â€œfirst-time positiveâ€ test results for GC/MS testing to confirm the results.Â  Rather, SCDC randomly sent a minimal number of tests to be confirmed by GC/MS testing in order to insure the accuracy of their â€œtest stripâ€ testing.Â  Furthermore, we disagree with the circuit courtâ€™s finding that to deny Skipperâ€™s request â€œupon Skipperâ€™s offer to pay for same [GC/MS testing] interferes with Skipperâ€™s right to due process in his disciplinary conviction.â€Â  Due process in prison drug testing does not require that a prisoner be afforded duplicative testing, nor does it require utilizing a testing method chosen by the prisoner.
CONCLUSION
Because Skipper has, during the course of his appeal, been transferred to a facility which does not provide his desired employment, we do not believe this court can grant any effectual relief. Â Nevertheless, in the interest of thoroughness, we address the merits of the appeal.Â  We hold the circuit court erred in finding as a matter of law that Skipperâ€™s dismissal from prison employment infringed upon a liberty interest and in finding SCDCâ€™s drug testing of Skipper violated his due process rights.Â  Based on the foregoing, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s order and find the ALJ should have dismissed Skipperâ€™s appeal given his grievance did not implicate a state-created liberty interest.5
 REVERSED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â Â  Skipper is serving a sentence of twenty years to life for murder and several counts of assault of a high and aggravated nature.
[3]Â Â  We note that Skipper has not challenged the circuit courtâ€™s findings that the disciplinary action will not affect his parole eligibility or that the loss of canteen privileges does not infringe on a liberty interest.
[4]Â Â Â  Additionally, we note that Skipper was employed in a state that recognizes the doctrine of employment at-will.Â  See Prescott v. Farmers Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 334, 516 S.E.2d 923, 925 (1999) (noting that South Carolina recognizes the doctrine of employment at-will).Â  Because Skipperâ€™s employment did not fit within any of the established exceptions to the at-will employment doctrine, his employment was terminable at any time by Prison Industries.Â  Thus, it would be incongruous to find Skipper had a state-created liberty interest in his employment.Â  See id. (â€œAt-will employment is generally terminable by either party at any time, for any reason or for no reason at all.â€); Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 6, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004) (outlining the following established exceptions to the at-will employment doctrine:Â  (1) an employee has recourse against his employer for termination in violation of public policy; (2) an at-will employee may not be terminated for exercising constitutional rights; and (3) an employee has a cause of action against an employer who contractually alters the at-will relationship and terminates the employee in violation of the contract). 
[5]Â Â  We believe the ALJ improperly dismissed Skipperâ€™s appeal on the ground that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction.Â  In light of our decision that Skipperâ€™s grievance did not implicate a state-created liberty interest, we find the ALJ had jurisdiction to dismiss the appeal on the merits.Â  See Slezak v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 361 S.C. 327, 331, 605 S.E.2d 506, 508 (2004), cert. denied, 544 U.S. 1033 (2005) (â€œWhile the ALJD has jurisdiction over all inmate grievance appeals that have been properly filed, we emphasize that the Division is not required to hold a hearing in every matter.Â  Summary dismissal may be appropriate where the inmateâ€™s grievance does not implicate a state-created liberty or property interest.â€).Â  We would, however, note that neither the ALJ nor the circuit court had the benefit of our supreme courtâ€™s decision in Slezak.
